defenses.defense: Use of the "Adopt Me!" name and related branding is lawful and non-infringing because it identifies a separate, independent game and brand that has developed its own recognition.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act defenses grounded in absence of infringement and fair use–style arguments (inferred from assertion that their game is distinct and not confusing).

defenses.defense: Certain allegations in the complaint are irrelevant, prejudicial, or overly inflammatory and should be removed from the pleadings.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(f) – motion to strike "redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous" matter.
defenses.outcome: Court granted the motion to strike in part, removing some paragraphs deemed insufficiently connected or hyperbolic, and denied it in part, leaving other challenged allegations in place.

case_name: Dzananovic v. Bumble Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves facial recognition and automated biometric processing in a dating app’s photo verification feature, raising issues about AI-driven biometric data collection and consent.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) § 15(b) for collecting or capturing biometric identifiers/biometric information via Bumble’s photo verification facial recognition feature without providing required written notice and obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to personal jurisdiction; BIPA § 15(b) claim allowed to proceed at this stage.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) § 15(a) for failing to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written policy establishing a retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers/biometric information collected through the app’s facial recognition feature.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to personal jurisdiction; BIPA § 15(a) claim allowed to proceed at this stage.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) § 15(d) for disclosing, redisclosing, or otherwise disseminating users’ biometric identifiers/biometric information obtained through the photo verification process without consent or statutory authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to personal jurisdiction; BIPA § 15(d) claim allowed to proceed at this stage.

claims.claim: Class action claim on behalf of Illinois users subjected to Bumble’s photo verification facial recognition process without BIPA-compliant notice, consent, and retention/disclosure practices.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23; Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: At motion-to-dismiss stage; court did not dismiss on jurisdictional grounds, allowing putative class claims to move forward.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Bumble and related entities because their contacts with Illinois were allegedly insufficient and the alleged BIPA violations were not sufficiently connected to Illinois.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; federal specific personal jurisdiction standards (minimum contacts and relatedness).

defenses.defense: Corporate separateness and lack of involvement by certain related entities, arguing that some defendants did not operate the app or direct activities toward Illinois and therefore should not be haled into Illinois court.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate law principles of separate corporate personality; federal personal jurisdiction doctrine as applied to parent/affiliate entities.

case_name: Overjet, Inc. v. Videa Health, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over competing dental AI systems for analyzing X-rays and alleged copying and misrepresentation of AI capabilities.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged copying of Overjet’s color schemes, shapes, and shading used to annotate dental X-rays in its AI software interface.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (Copyright Act).
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court found Overjet had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits of its copyright claim at this stage.

claims.claim: False advertising regarding Videa’s AI capabilities and performance in the marketplace, allegedly misleading customers about the nature and quality of Videa’s dental AI product.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act false advertising provisions.
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court held Overjet had not demonstrated a likelihood of success on the false advertising claim or irreparable harm.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop Videa from using the challenged annotations and from engaging in alleged false advertising during the litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy standard for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, public interest).
claims.outcome: Motion for preliminary injunction denied in full; court found no sufficient showing of likelihood of success on the merits or irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: The color, shape, and shading choices for annotating dental X-rays are not protectable by copyright (e.g., functional, generic, or lacking originality).
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law limitations on protectable subject matter and idea–expression dichotomy.

defenses.defense: Videa’s advertising about its AI capabilities is not false or misleading, or any statements are non-actionable puffery rather than factual misrepresentations.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act standards for false advertising and puffery.

defenses.defense: Overjet cannot show irreparable harm or entitlement to extraordinary relief, so a preliminary injunction is inappropriate even if some claims might ultimately succeed.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standards governing preliminary injunctions (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of hardships, public interest).

case_id: 2021-06-14_USCOURTS-txsd-4_20-cv-03315_Omoyosi v. Texas Health and Human Services Commission.pdf
case_name: Omoyosi v. Texas Health and Human Services Commission
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.claim: Failure to hire plaintiff for multiple positions because of his race
claims.legal_basis: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (race discrimination in employment)
claims.outcome: Dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) for failure to state a plausible claim of racial discrimination; defendant’s motion to dismiss granted

claims.claim: Challenge to Texas Health & Human Services Commission’s handling and policies regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, including requests to change or improve pandemic response
claims.legal_basis: Constitutional and statutory claims framed as requests for injunctive and declaratory relief (non-employment related)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; plaintiff failed to show a concrete, particularized injury traceable to defendant’s COVID-19 response

claims.claim: Requests for broad injunctive relief compelling changes to defendant’s policies and practices (including COVID-19 measures and possibly hiring practices)
claims.legal_basis: Equitable relief ancillary to Title VII and other asserted federal claims
claims.outcome: Denied and dismissed because underlying claims were dismissed (no standing, failure to state a claim, and sovereign immunity)

claims.claim: Additional or expanded claims proposed in a further amended complaint
claims.legal_basis: Proposed amendments under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15
claims.outcome: Leave to further amend denied as futile because proposed amendments would not cure standing, sovereign immunity, or pleading deficiencies

claims.claim: Claims for damages and other relief against the state agency beyond the scope of Title VII’s waiver
claims.legal_basis: Various federal and possibly state-law theories barred by Eleventh Amendment sovereign immunity
claims.outcome: Dismissed as barred by sovereign immunity; court held it lacked jurisdiction over those claims

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks Article III standing to challenge the agency’s COVID-19 response and related policies
defenses.legal_basis: Article III of the U.S. Constitution; Rule 12(b)(1) lack of subject-matter jurisdiction

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a plausible claim of race discrimination in hiring
defenses.legal_basis: Title VII pleading standards; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and Twombly/Iqbal plausibility standard

defenses.defense: Sovereign immunity bars certain claims and requested relief against the state agency
defenses.legal_basis: Eleventh Amendment sovereign immunity and limits on suits against state agencies in federal court

defenses.defense: Proposed further amendment of the complaint would be futile
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a); futility doctrine for denying leave to amend

defenses.defense: Some requested injunctive and declaratory relief exceeds the court’s remedial authority
defenses.legal_basis: Limits on federal equitable relief and justiciability doctrines (including separation of powers and redressability requirements)

case_id: 2022-01-27_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation (Macy’s Retail Holdings, LLC)
ai_relevance: AI-based facial recognition database allegedly used to identify individuals from surveillance footage without consent, raising biometric privacy and data protection issues.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for collecting, capturing, or otherwise obtaining biometric identifiers and information without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiffs plausibly alleged BIPA violations and concrete injury, so BIPA claims proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for failing to provide and publish a written retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers and information
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim sufficiently pled and allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for disclosing or otherwise disseminating biometric identifiers and information without consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; disclosure-based BIPA claims allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for profiting from or otherwise benefiting from individuals’ biometric identifiers and information
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; plaintiffs plausibly alleged Macy’s profited from use of Clearview AI’s biometric database.

claims.claim: Violation of California consumer protection and privacy laws based on unauthorized use of biometric data via Clearview AI
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq., and related California statutory/privacy provisions
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed; certain California UCL and related state-law claims were dismissed for insufficient allegations, while other California-based claims (to the extent adequately pled) were allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of New York statutory and common law privacy protections through unauthorized collection and use of biometric data
claims.legal_basis: New York privacy statutes and common law (including claims pled alongside unjust enrichment)
claims.outcome: Some New York-based claims survived the motion to dismiss, but the separate unjust enrichment claim under New York common law was dismissed.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on Macy’s alleged benefit from using Clearview AI’s biometric database without compensating or obtaining consent from affected individuals
claims.legal_basis: New York common law of unjust enrichment
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held the unjust enrichment claim under New York law was not sufficiently supported or was duplicative of other claims.

claims.claim: Unfair business practices by using AI-driven facial recognition technology to identify consumers without notice or consent
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed to the extent based solely on UCL theories the court found inadequately pled; other overlapping privacy-based theories proceed under different statutes.

defenses.defense: Lack of Article III standing because plaintiffs did not suffer a concrete injury from Macy’s alleged use of Clearview AI’s facial recognition database
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; Spokeo and related federal standing precedent
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found unauthorized collection and use of biometric data under BIPA constitutes a concrete injury sufficient for standing.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim under BIPA because Macy’s did not itself collect or control plaintiffs’ biometric data in a way covered by the statute
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); interpretation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court held plaintiffs plausibly alleged Macy’s used Clearview AI’s database in a manner that could violate BIPA, allowing BIPA claims to proceed.

defenses.defense: California Unfair Competition Law and related state-law claims are inadequately pled, including lack of economic injury and insufficient unlawful, unfair, or fraudulent conduct allegations
defenses.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq.; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6)
defenses.outcome: Partially accepted; court dismissed certain California UCL and related claims while allowing others grounded in adequately alleged privacy violations to continue.

defenses.defense: New York unjust enrichment and related common law claims are duplicative of other statutory claims or lack necessary elements such as direct benefit and inequity
defenses.legal_basis: New York common law of unjust enrichment; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6)
defenses.outcome: Accepted as to unjust enrichment; the New York unjust enrichment claim was dismissed.

case_id: 2022-03-30_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_20-cv-03873_Citizens Insurance Company Of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Citizens Insurance Company of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from use and sale of access to Clearview AI’s facial recognition database, an AI-based biometric identification system, allegedly in violation of Illinois BIPA; insurance coverage hinges on whether policy excludes defense for such AI-driven biometric privacy claims.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Citizens Insurance has no duty to defend Wynndalco in underlying class-action lawsuits alleging violations of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).
claims.legal_basis: Interpretation of commercial general liability insurance policy terms, including coverage grants and exclusions, and application of statutory violation exclusion to BIPA claims under Illinois contract and insurance law.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court held the statutory violation exclusion was ambiguous as applied to BIPA, construed the ambiguity in favor of the insured, and ruled that Citizens has a duty to defend Wynndalco in the underlying BIPA class actions.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Citizens Insurance has no duty to indemnify Wynndalco for any liability arising from the underlying BIPA class-action lawsuits.
claims.legal_basis: Same insurance policy interpretation, focusing on whether BIPA claims fall outside the scope of covered “personal and advertising injury” and are barred by the statutory violation exclusion.
claims.outcome: Not fully resolved on the merits in the provided summary; the court’s decision squarely addresses and rejects Citizens’ position on the duty to defend, and the indemnity question remains at least partially unresolved or dependent on further proceedings and the outcome of the underlying suits.

defenses.defense: The statutory violation exclusion in the insurance policy bars coverage for claims alleging violations of BIPA, so Citizens owes no duty to defend or indemnify Wynndalco.
defenses.legal_basis: Policy exclusion for injuries arising out of violations of certain statutes regulating the sending, transmitting, or communicating of information, interpreted by Citizens to encompass BIPA’s regulation of biometric information.

defenses.defense: The BIPA-based class actions do not fall within the policy’s definition of covered “personal and advertising injury,” so there is no initial grant of coverage.
defenses.legal_basis: Construction of the policy’s insuring agreement and definitions to argue that alleged biometric privacy violations are outside the scope of covered offenses.

case_id: 2025-01-17_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_22-cv-00046_Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Use of Lytx’s machine-vision and AI (MV+AI) system in DriveCam to monitor drivers and predict distracted driving allegedly involved collection and storage of biometric data without informed consent, triggering Illinois BIPA privacy and data‑protection claims and driving the settlement.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and biometric information from drivers via Lytx’s DriveCam MV+AI system without obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – collection without written notice and release.
claims.outcome: Included in class action settlement; court granted preliminary approval of a $4.25 million non-reversionary settlement fund, subject to final approval, with no admission of liability by defendants.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and retention of drivers’ biometric identifiers and information captured by the MV+AI system without a publicly available retention schedule and destruction policy, and without complying with required retention limits.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) – retention schedule and destruction requirements.
claims.outcome: Resolved as part of the same class action settlement; preliminarily approved by the court as fair, reasonable, and adequate, pending final approval.

claims.claim: Unlawful disclosure or dissemination of drivers’ biometric identifiers and information to third parties through or in connection with the DriveCam MV+AI system without proper consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) – disclosure or dissemination without consent.
claims.outcome: Covered by the global class action settlement; preliminarily approved by the court, with final approval hearing to determine permanent resolution.

claims.claim: Failure to use reasonable standards of care and industry-standard safeguards to protect drivers’ biometric identifiers and information collected through the MV+AI system.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(e) – duty of care and data security for biometric data.
claims.outcome: Resolved through the preliminarily approved class settlement; monetary relief and class certification granted on a preliminary basis, subject to final approval.

defenses.defense: Denial that the data collected by the DriveCam MV+AI system constitutes “biometric identifiers” or “biometric information” under BIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act definitions (740 ILCS 14/10).

defenses.defense: Assertion that any collection or use of data was consented to or authorized by drivers or their employers, or otherwise compliant with BIPA requirements.
defenses.legal_basis: Compliance and consent defenses under Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and general contract/authorization principles.

defenses.defense: Argument that class certification requirements (commonality, predominance, typicality, adequacy) were not met for litigation purposes.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 – class certification standards.

defenses.defense: Settlement without admission of liability, fault, or wrongdoing regarding any alleged BIPA violations.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard class action settlement terms preserving defendants’ denial of liability.

case_id: 2023-08-10_USCOURTS-ctd-3_22-cv-01065_Flynn et al v. Verizon Wireless et al.pdf
case_name: Flynn et al. v. Verizon Wireless et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged 5G networks enabled secretive data collection through AI, but the court treated these AI-related conspiracy allegations as implausible and insufficient to establish standing or a viable claim.

claims.claim: Conspiracy to use 5G networks in Connecticut to control the population and cause harm through secretive data collection and other injuries.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil rights and constitutional violations (implied), general conspiracy and tort theories (not clearly specified).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of standing and failure to state a plausible claim; plaintiff did not allege a concrete, particularized injury or facts linking harms to specific defendants. Leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Use of 5G and related technologies, including AI-driven data collection, to conduct secret surveillance and violate privacy rights of the population, including plaintiff.
claims.legal_basis: Implied constitutional privacy and civil rights claims (not clearly articulated).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of standing and implausibility; no specific, personal, concrete injury or factual basis pled. Leave to amend granted if plaintiff can allege particularized harm.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks Article III standing because he failed to allege a concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent injury traceable to defendants and redressable by the court.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III of the U.S. Constitution; federal standing doctrine requiring concrete and particularized injury-in-fact.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a plausible claim for relief because allegations of a broad 5G conspiracy and AI-based secret data collection are conclusory and unsupported by specific facts tying conduct to particular defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); plausibility standard under Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly and Ashcroft v. Iqbal.

case_name: Admiin Inc. d/b/a Paro Inc. v. Luke Kohan and FirmKey Solutions LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-powered finance marketplace allegedly protecting confidential algorithms, data, and trade secrets from ex-employee’s competing venture.

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete agreement by former employee
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing enforceability and breach of restrictive covenants in employment agreements
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff had not shown a sufficient likelihood of success on the merits at the TRO stage and denied temporary restraining order based on this claim.

claims.claim: Threatened or inevitable misappropriation of trade secrets
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law, including the doctrine of inevitable disclosure (likely under state trade secrets statute and/or DTSA principles)
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiff did not show a likelihood of success because there was insufficient evidence of actual or imminent misappropriation and denied TRO on this ground.

claims.claim: Request for temporary restraining order to bar competition and use of confidential information
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief standards requiring likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, balance of harms, and public interest
claims.outcome: Court denied the request for a temporary restraining order in full, finding no adequate showing of likelihood of success on the underlying claims and concerns about overbreadth of the non-compete.

defenses.defense: Non-compete agreement is overbroad and unenforceable
defenses.legal_basis: State contract and employment law limiting restrictive covenants that unreasonably restrain trade or are broader than necessary to protect legitimate business interests.

defenses.defense: No actual or threatened misappropriation of trade secrets
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requiring proof of acquisition, disclosure, or use (or sufficiently concrete threat) of trade secrets; challenge to application of inevitable disclosure doctrine.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff cannot meet TRO standard, including likelihood of success on the merits
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standards for temporary restraining orders and preliminary injunctions under federal procedural law (e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 65) and relevant circuit precedent.

case_id: 2024-06-27_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-05096_Tibbs et al v. Arlo Technologies_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Tibbs et al. v. Arlo Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Case concerns Arlo’s AI-powered facial recognition and related automated biometric features used in home security systems to capture, analyze, and store individuals’ biometric data without proper consent or policies.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection and capture of biometric identifiers and biometric information without informed written consent from the delivery drivers.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), including provisions governing collection and capture of biometric identifiers/information (e.g., 740 ILCS 14/15(b)).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed as plausibly alleged BIPA violations and supported Article III standing.

claims.claim: Failure to provide and make publicly available a written policy establishing a retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers and information.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), including provisions requiring a publicly available data retention and destruction policy (e.g., 740 ILCS 14/15(a)).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed as plaintiffs sufficiently alleged absence of a compliant retention and destruction policy.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and retention of biometric identifiers and information without compliant retention limits or destruction practices.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), including provisions restricting retention and mandating timely destruction of biometric data (e.g., 740 ILCS 14/15(a), 15(d)).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed based on plausible allegations that Arlo retained biometric data longer than permitted and without proper safeguards.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they did not suffer a concrete injury from the alleged biometric data practices.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, Article III standing requirements; federal justiciability doctrines regarding injury-in-fact, causation, and redressability.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; the court found plaintiffs alleged concrete privacy and statutory harms sufficient for Article III standing and allowed the case to proceed.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim under BIPA because Arlo’s conduct is not covered by the statute or the allegations are insufficiently specific or plausible.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); interpretation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act scope and pleading standards.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; the court held that plaintiffs plausibly alleged that Arlo’s biometric collection and retention practices fall within BIPA and stated viable claims.

defenses.defense: Motion to strike plaintiffs’ supplemental authority as improper or irrelevant to the court’s consideration of the motion to dismiss.
defenses.legal_basis: Procedural rules and court’s inherent authority to manage briefing and evidentiary submissions on motions.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; the court denied Arlo’s motion to strike supplemental authority and considered plaintiffs’ submissions.

case_id: 2022-02-14_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI facial-recognition algorithms to scrape, analyze, and sell biometric data, forming the core of the alleged privacy and BIPA violations.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for collecting, capturing, and obtaining biometric identifiers and information without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiffs adequately alleged BIPA violations based on Clearview’s AI-driven scraping and analysis of facial biometrics without consent.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for improper disclosure, dissemination, and sale of biometric identifiers and information
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court found allegations sufficient that Clearview sold and provided access to biometric data to third parties without proper consent.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for failure to develop and publish a retention schedule and destruction guidelines for biometric data
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiffs plausibly alleged Clearview lacked and failed to publish a compliant retention and destruction policy for biometric data.

claims.claim: State-law privacy and related statutory claims based on unauthorized collection and use of biometric and facial data
claims.legal_basis: Various state privacy and consumer protection laws (non-Illinois)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss largely denied; court held plaintiffs sufficiently alleged privacy and statutory violations in multiple states arising from Clearview’s AI-based facial recognition practices.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment under New York law based on profits derived from unlawfully obtained biometric data
claims.legal_basis: New York common law of unjust enrichment
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; court held the New York unjust enrichment claim was preempted or displaced by existing law and could not proceed.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for BIPA and other privacy violations
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); argument that allegations did not meet statutory elements or plausibility standard.

defenses.defense: Preemption or displacement of certain state-law claims, including New York unjust enrichment
defenses.legal_basis: State preemption and displacement doctrines under New York and other applicable state laws.

defenses.defense: Challenges to extraterritorial application and scope of state privacy statutes
defenses.legal_basis: State statutory interpretation principles limiting reach of privacy statutes beyond state borders.

case_name: Jones v. Peloton Interactive, Inc.
ai_relevance: Embedded chat software allegedly intercepted and used website chat data to improve AI technologies, raising privacy and eavesdropping issues.

claims.claim: Violation of the California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) § 631(a) for unlawful interception and recording of website chat communications via embedded Drift software
claims.legal_basis: California Invasion of Privacy Act, Cal. Penal Code § 631(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged a CIPA § 631(a) claim based on Drift acting as a third-party eavesdropper using chat data for its own purposes.

defenses.defense: Drift acted merely as Peloton’s tool or agent, not as a separate third-party eavesdropper, so there was no unlawful interception under CIPA § 631(a)
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of California Invasion of Privacy Act, Cal. Penal Code § 631(a), and agency principles

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a plausible claim because the alleged conduct falls outside the scope of CIPA’s prohibition on third-party eavesdropping
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and statutory interpretation of CIPA § 631(a)

case_id: 2006-12-05_USCOURTS-cand-3_00-cv-04263_Werner_ et al v. Quintus Corporation_ et al.pdf
case_name: Werner et al. v. Quintus Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false and misleading statements in Quintus Corporation’s IPO registration statement and subsequent financial disclosures, which allegedly overstated the company’s financial condition and prospects, causing investors to purchase stock at artificially inflated prices.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 11 and/or Section 12 of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 (misrepresentations and omissions in offering materials and public filings).
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court approved a $10.1 million settlement as fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class, along with the proposed plan of allocation.

claims.claim: Class action claims for damages on behalf of all purchasers of Quintus Corporation stock during the relevant class period who were allegedly harmed by the artificial inflation of the stock price due to the company’s misstatements.
claims.legal_basis: Federal class action procedure under Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure combined with substantive federal securities law claims.
claims.outcome: Class certification and settlement approved; class members entitled to share in the $10.1 million settlement fund according to the court-approved plan of allocation.

claims.claim: Application for attorney’s fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities fraud class action.
claims.legal_basis: Court’s equitable authority in class actions and applicable standards for awarding reasonable attorney’s fees and costs from a common fund in securities class actions.
claims.outcome: Court granted the application, approving attorney’s fees and reimbursement of expenses as reasonable in light of the results obtained and the risks of continued litigation.

defenses.defense: Litigation risk and uncertainty, including challenges to proving falsity, scienter, loss causation, and damages, as well as potential defenses to liability under the federal securities laws.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive defenses under the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including lack of material misrepresentation, lack of scienter, and failure to prove loss causation or damages.

defenses.defense: Bankruptcy and financial condition of Quintus Corporation limiting the practical ability of plaintiffs to recover a larger judgment even if they prevailed at trial.
defenses.legal_basis: Bankruptcy law constraints on recovery and collectability, affecting the reasonableness of settlement under Rule 23(e) standards for fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy.

defenses.defense: Arguments that the proposed settlement amount and allocation were reasonable in light of the strengths and weaknesses of the case, the costs and delay of further litigation, and the risks of trial and appeal.
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for approval of class action settlements under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e), focusing on fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy of the compromise.

case_name: Tuopshug v. Quintus Corporation, et al.
ai_relevance: Quintus sold eCRM software that used artificial intelligence to power customer relationship management solutions; alleged misstatements concerned the financial performance of this AI-enabled product business.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on misleading and false financial statements and disclosures during the class period, which allegedly inflated Quintus’s stock price and harmed investors who purchased Quintus securities.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing material misstatements and omissions in connection with the purchase or sale of securities.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class settlement of $10.1 million; court found the settlement, plan of allocation, and requested attorneys’ fees and expenses to be fair, reasonable, and adequate and granted final approval.

defenses.defense: Further litigation would be uncertain and risky for plaintiffs due to challenges in proving falsity, scienter, loss causation, and damages, especially in light of Quintus’s bankruptcy and limited resources.
defenses.legal_basis: General securities-litigation defenses regarding lack of sufficient evidence to establish elements under Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, and practical limitations arising from bankruptcy and collectability concerns.

case_name: Khalil v. Quintus Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on misleading and overstated financial statements in connection with Quintus Corporation’s IPO and subsequent financial reports, which allegedly inflated the company’s stock price and caused investor losses when the truth emerged and the company later went bankrupt.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misrepresentations and omissions in public company disclosures and offering materials.
claims.outcome: Resolved through a court-approved class action settlement of $10.1 million, found fair, reasonable, and adequate; claims were released in exchange for the settlement payment to class members.

defenses.defense: Continued litigation posed high risk and uncertainty for plaintiffs, including challenges in proving falsity, scienter, loss causation, and damages, as well as potential difficulties in recovering additional funds given Quintus’s financial condition and bankruptcy.
defenses.legal_basis: Practical and legal litigation-risk considerations under federal securities law standards for class certification, liability, and damages, supporting approval of a negotiated settlement rather than adjudication on the merits.

defenses.defense: Limited resources available from Quintus’s bankruptcy estate constrained the potential recovery, making the negotiated settlement a reasonable compromise compared to the uncertain outcome of further litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Bankruptcy law constraints on available assets and general principles governing evaluation of class action settlements in light of defendants’ ability to pay.

defenses.defense: Absence of objections from class members and their generally favorable reaction to the settlement supported the conclusion that the compromise was fair and adequate.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for approval of class action settlements, including consideration of class members’ response and lack of opposition as factors favoring approval.

case_name: Yu v. Quintus Corporation, et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on materially false and misleading financial statements and disclosures that overstated Quintus Corporation’s financial condition and prospects, artificially inflating its stock price during the class period.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misrepresentations and omissions in connection with the purchase or sale of securities.
claims.outcome: Resolved by a court-approved class action settlement of approximately $10.1 million; the court found the settlement, including the plan of allocation, to be fair, reasonable, and adequate under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e).

claims.claim: Class claims for damages suffered by investors who purchased Quintus Corporation securities at artificially inflated prices and later incurred losses when the truth about the company’s financial condition emerged and the company went bankrupt.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities class action principles under Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, in conjunction with substantive rights under the federal securities laws.
claims.outcome: Damages claims were satisfied on a compromise basis through the approved settlement fund and plan of allocation; individual class members’ recoveries were determined pursuant to the court-approved allocation formula.

claims.claim: Application for award of attorney fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities fraud class action on behalf of the class.
claims.legal_basis: Court’s equitable authority in class actions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(h) and common-fund doctrine applicable in securities class actions.
claims.outcome: Court granted the motion, approving attorney fees and expense reimbursement as reasonable in amount and proportion to the benefit conferred on the class.

defenses.defense: The proposed settlement and plan of allocation are fair, reasonable, and adequate in light of the risks, costs, and delays of continued securities litigation and Quintus Corporation’s bankruptcy.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for approval of class action settlements, including factors such as risk, complexity, and likelihood of recovery.

defenses.defense: The requested attorney fees and expense reimbursements are reasonable given the results achieved, the complexity and duration of the litigation, and prevailing fee benchmarks in securities class actions.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(h) and common-fund doctrine, including case law on percentage-of-the-fund and lodestar cross-check analyses for fee awards.

case_name: Magnan v. Quintus Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: Quintus sold e-CRM software with AI-like automated customer interaction tools; alleged securities fraud concerned this AI-focused business.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false and misleading statements about Quintus’s financial condition and business prospects in public filings and securities offerings, causing investor losses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misstatements and omissions in connection with the purchase or sale of securities.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class settlement of $10.1 million; court found the settlement fair, reasonable, and adequate and entered final approval.

claims.claim: Class-wide recovery and distribution of settlement proceeds to investors who purchased Quintus securities during the class period and were damaged by the alleged fraud.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 governing class actions and court’s equitable authority to approve a plan of allocation in securities class settlements.
claims.outcome: Court approved the proposed plan of allocation as fair and reasonable and ordered distribution of the $10.1 million settlement fund according to that plan.

claims.claim: Application for award of attorney fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities fraud class action.
claims.legal_basis: Court’s equitable authority in class actions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(h) and common-fund doctrine for fee awards from settlement funds.
claims.outcome: Court granted the application, approving attorney fees and expense reimbursement as reasonable in light of the results obtained and risks of the litigation.

defenses.defense: The settlement and plan of allocation are fair, reasonable, and adequate to the class and should be finally approved, resolving all claims without admission of liability.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for approval of class action settlements and case law favoring settlement of complex securities litigation.

claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misrepresentations and omissions in connection with the purchase or sale of securities.
claims.outcome: Resolved by a court-approved class settlement of approximately $10.1 million; the court granted final approval, finding the settlement fair, reasonable, and adequate for the class members.

claims.claim: Application for attorney fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities fraud class action on behalf of the class.

claims.outcome: Court granted the application, awarding attorney fees and reimbursement of expenses as requested (or as adjusted by the court), finding them reasonable in light of the results obtained and risks undertaken.

defenses.defense: Settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate given the risks, costs, and delay of continued securities fraud litigation and the uncertainties of proving liability, damages, and collectability, especially in light of Quintus’s Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

case_name: Micnaud v. Quintus Corporation, et al.
ai_relevance: Case involves alleged securities fraud by a company selling AI-based “eContact” e-CRM software; the AI product and related technology were central to the company’s business and the allegedly misleading statements that inflated stock prices.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false and misleading statements about Quintus Corporation’s financial condition and business prospects, which allegedly inflated the market price of its stock during the class period.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws (e.g., Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5) and related class action provisions.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class action settlement of $10.1 million; court found the settlement fair, reasonable, and adequate and ordered distribution to eligible investors.

claims.claim: Class action claim for damages suffered by investors who purchased Quintus securities at artificially inflated prices due to the alleged misrepresentations and omissions.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities class action provisions (including Section 20(a) “control person” liability and Rule 23 class action rules).
claims.outcome: Class certified for settlement purposes; court granted final approval of the settlement and plan of allocation, providing monetary recovery to class members.

claims.claim: Request for attorney fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities class action on behalf of the investor class.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable fee-shifting principles in class actions and applicable federal securities class action fee standards.
claims.outcome: Court granted the application for attorney fees and expenses as part of the final approval order, finding the requested amounts reasonable in light of the recovery obtained.

defenses.defense: The settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate and should be approved, resolving all claims without further litigation risk or expense.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for approval of class action settlements and case law on fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy.

case_name: Alves v. Quintus Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: Defendant’s business involved AI-related “eCRM” software solutions, and alleged securities fraud concerned misstatements about revenues and performance of this AI-enabled technology company during and after its IPO.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on materially false and misleading statements and omissions about Quintus Corporation’s revenues, financial condition, and business prospects in connection with its IPO and subsequent public filings during 1999–2000.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misrepresentations in connection with the purchase or sale of securities; class action procedures under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class action settlement of $10.1 million; court found the settlement and allocation plan fair, reasonable, and adequate and entered final approval, extinguishing the class’s securities fraud claims against Quintus and related defendants.

claims.claim: Class action claim for damages on behalf of all investors who purchased Quintus Corporation securities during the class period and were harmed by the alleged misrepresentations and omissions.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 for class certification and maintenance of a securities fraud class action, in conjunction with federal securities statutes and regulations.
claims.outcome: Class treatment confirmed for settlement purposes; court approved the settlement and distribution plan, providing monetary recovery to eligible class members and releasing defendants from further class claims.

claims.claim: Application for attorney fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred by lead plaintiff’s counsel in prosecuting the securities fraud class action.
claims.legal_basis: Court’s equitable authority in class actions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(h) and applicable precedent allowing reasonable attorney fees and costs from a common settlement fund.
claims.outcome: Court granted the application, approving attorney fees and reimbursement of expenses to be paid from the $10.1 million settlement fund.

defenses.defense: The proposed settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate in light of litigation risks, potential defenses on liability and damages, and the costs and uncertainties of continued litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for class action settlements under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e), requiring judicial finding that the compromise is fair, reasonable, and adequate to the class.

defenses.defense: Implicit defenses to the underlying securities fraud allegations, including potential arguments that any misstatements were not material, not made with scienter, or did not cause the claimed investor losses, thereby limiting or defeating liability and damages.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive requirements for securities fraud under Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5, including elements of material misrepresentation or omission, scienter, reliance, loss causation, and damages.

case_name: Kaplowitz v. Quintus Corporation, et al.
ai_relevance: Defendant developed AI-based e-CRM software central to its business; alleged misrepresentations concerned the company’s financial condition and value, which were tied to this AI technology and its commercial prospects.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false and misleading statements and omissions about Quintus Corporation’s financial condition and business prospects in connection with the purchase of Quintus stock during the class period.
claims.legal_basis: Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class action settlement; plaintiffs’ claims were released in exchange for a $10.1 million settlement fund to be distributed under the approved plan of allocation.

claims.claim: Securities fraud and misrepresentation in offering materials related to Quintus Corporation’s initial public offering (IPO), including alleged inaccuracies in registration statements and prospectuses regarding the company’s financial status and business operations.
claims.legal_basis: Sections 11, 12(a)(2), and 15 of the Securities Act of 1933.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class action settlement; claims were released as part of the $10.1 million settlement, with no adjudication on the merits.

claims.claim: Request for approval of a plan of allocation to distribute the settlement fund among class members who purchased Quintus stock during the class period.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) governing fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy of class action settlements and distributions.
claims.outcome: Court granted final approval of the plan of allocation as fair, reasonable, and adequate; settlement funds to be distributed to eligible class members accordingly.

claims.claim: Application for attorneys’ fees and reimbursement of litigation expenses incurred in prosecuting the securities class action.
claims.legal_basis: Court’s equitable authority in class actions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(h) and common-fund doctrine.
claims.outcome: Court approved the requested attorneys’ fees and expense reimbursement as reasonable in light of the $10.1 million recovery and the complexity and risk of the litigation.

defenses.defense: Denial of liability for securities fraud, including denial that any statements or omissions about Quintus’s financial condition or business prospects were materially false or misleading or caused investor losses.
defenses.legal_basis: General defenses under the Securities Act of 1933 and Securities Exchange Act of 1934, including lack of scienter, immateriality, and absence of loss causation.

defenses.defense: Assertion that the proposed settlement was a compromise to avoid the burden, expense, and uncertainty of continued litigation and did not constitute an admission of wrongdoing or liability.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard no-admission-of-liability provisions in class action settlements under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e).

case_id: 2006-12-05_USCOURTS-cand-3_00-cv-04392_Miller_ et al v. Quintus Corporation_ et al.pdf
case_name: Miller et al. v. Quintus Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: Quintus originally sold artificial intelligence software; alleged misstatements concerned revenues from its AI-related business.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false and misleading financial statements and disclosures in connection with Quintus Corporation’s IPO and subsequent public filings, which allegedly overstated revenues and misrepresented the company’s financial condition, causing investors to purchase Quintus stock at artificially inflated prices and suffer losses when the truth emerged and the stock price collapsed.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities laws, including Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions governing misstatements and omissions in connection with the purchase or sale of securities; potentially Sections 11 and 12 of the Securities Act of 1933 for IPO-related misstatements.
claims.outcome: Settled on a class-wide basis; the court granted final approval of a $10.1 million settlement as fair, reasonable, and adequate, resolving the securities fraud claims without trial.

defenses.defense: The proposed class action settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate in light of Quintus’s financial condition, the risks and uncertainties of continued litigation, and the comprehensive nature of the global resolution among various litigants.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for approval of class action settlements, including factors such as risk, expense, complexity, and likely duration of further litigation, the amount offered in settlement, and the reaction of the class.

defenses.defense: Absence of objections from class members supports approval of the settlement and indicates that the class views the compromise as fair and reasonable.
defenses.legal_basis: Class action settlement jurisprudence under Rule 23(e), which treats the lack of objections or opt-outs as evidence of the settlement’s fairness and adequacy.

case_name: Jones v. Patents and Trademarks Commissioner
ai_relevance: Plaintiff’s alleged inventions involve artificial intelligence and related technologies (including “Fractal mathematics” and other AI-related intellectual property) that he claims were wrongfully used by Google and for which he sought patent protection.

claims.claim: Failure by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office to provide necessary forms and assistance to apply for patents on plaintiff’s artificial intelligence and related intellectual property, including “Fractal mathematics” and other technologies.
claims.legal_basis: Implied constitutional and statutory claim regarding access to the patent system and government services (construed as a civil rights / administrative access claim).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found plaintiff could not proceed in forma pauperis due to three-strikes bar under the PLRA and, independently, that the complaint failed to state a plausible legal claim.

claims.claim: Improper or wrongful use of plaintiff’s artificial intelligence-related intellectual property by Google, allegedly enabled or not prevented by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office’s failure to process or provide patent application materials.
claims.legal_basis: Implied claim sounding in intellectual property infringement or misappropriation, indirectly asserted against government actors (no clear statutory or common-law basis articulated).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court held the complaint did not state a cognizable legal claim linking the defendants to any actionable infringement or misappropriation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is barred from proceeding in forma pauperis because he has accumulated more than three prior actions dismissed as frivolous, malicious, or for failure to state a claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Prison Litigation Reform Act, 28 U.S.C. § 1915(g) three-strikes provision.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because it does not plausibly allege a legal duty breached by defendants or a cognizable cause of action related to patent application forms or alleged use of plaintiff’s ideas.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and screening standards under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1915(e)(2), 1915A.

case_name: D’Agostino v. Innodata Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged misstatements about company’s AI technology and capabilities underpin the securities-fraud class action.

claims.claim: Securities fraud based on false or misleading statements about Innodata’s artificial intelligence technology and related business prospects, brought as a putative securities class action.
claims.legal_basis: Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5, and related provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act (PSLRA).
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided in this opinion; the court only resolved competing motions for appointment of lead plaintiff and lead counsel, leaving the underlying securities-fraud claims pending.

claims.claim: Request for appointment of a lead plaintiff to represent the putative securities class in litigation against Innodata for alleged securities fraud.
claims.legal_basis: Private Securities Litigation Reform Act (PSLRA), 15 U.S.C. § 78u-4(a)(3), governing selection of the “most adequate plaintiff.”
claims.outcome: Granted as to Francis Grondin; the court held that Grondin has the largest financial interest, satisfies Rule 23 typicality and adequacy requirements, and is therefore appointed lead plaintiff.

claims.claim: Request for approval of selected lead counsel and local counsel to represent the class under the direction of the lead plaintiff.
claims.legal_basis: PSLRA, 15 U.S.C. § 78u-4(a)(3)(B)(v), and the court’s inherent authority to supervise class counsel appointments under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(g).
claims.outcome: Granted; the court approved Grondin’s chosen lead counsel and local counsel as appropriate and adequate to represent the class.

claims.claim: Competing motion by Curtis Gardner seeking appointment as lead plaintiff for the same putative securities class.
claims.legal_basis: PSLRA, 15 U.S.C. § 78u-4(a)(3), asserting his own adequacy and financial interest to serve as lead plaintiff.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court found Gardner did not have the largest financial interest compared to Grondin and therefore was not the presumptive lead plaintiff under the PSLRA.

defenses.defense: Challenge to competing movant’s adequacy and financial interest, arguing that the other proposed lead plaintiff was not the “most adequate plaintiff” under the PSLRA.
defenses.legal_basis: PSLRA’s “most adequate plaintiff” standard, 15 U.S.C. § 78u-4(a)(3)(B), and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 typicality and adequacy requirements.

case_name: Gray v. Experian Information Solutions, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff used AI transcription tool to generate a transcript of a disputed phone call offered as evidence; court found the AI-generated transcript unreliable and inadmissible, but AI was not itself the subject of the legal claim.

claims.claim: Inaccurate reporting of plaintiff’s credit information on his consumer credit report
claims.legal_basis: Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), including 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(b) duty to follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Experian; court found plaintiff failed to present admissible evidence of any actual inaccuracy in the Experian credit report and thus could not establish a prima facie FCRA violation.

claims.claim: Failure to conduct reasonable reinvestigation and correct disputed information after plaintiff’s disputes
claims.legal_basis: Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), including 15 U.S.C. § 1681i(a) duty to reinvestigate disputed information
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Experian; court held plaintiff did not provide admissible evidence showing inaccurate information persisted after disputes or that Experian’s reinvestigation procedures were unreasonable.

claims.claim: Damages for credit denials and other adverse credit actions allegedly caused by Experian’s inaccurate reporting
claims.legal_basis: Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) provisions allowing recovery of actual damages for negligent or willful noncompliance, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681n, 1681o
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Experian; court found no admissible evidence that any adverse credit decisions were caused by Experian’s reporting, so plaintiff failed to prove actual damages.

claims.claim: Damages for emotional distress allegedly resulting from Experian’s inaccurate reporting and failure to correct errors
claims.legal_basis: Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) damages provisions, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681n, 1681o (emotional distress as a form of actual damages)
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Experian; court concluded plaintiff’s evidence of emotional distress was insufficient and not adequately linked to any proven FCRA violation or inaccuracy.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff cannot show any inaccurate information in his Experian credit report
defenses.legal_basis: Element of an FCRA claim under 15 U.S.C. § 1681e(b) and § 1681i requires proof of inaccuracy; absence of inaccuracy defeats liability and supports summary judgment.

defenses.defense: Experian followed reasonable procedures and conducted appropriate reinvestigations of plaintiff’s disputes
defenses.legal_basis: Compliance with FCRA duties under 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681e(b) and 1681i; if procedures and reinvestigation are reasonable, no FCRA violation exists.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks admissible evidence of causation between Experian’s reporting and any alleged credit denials or adverse actions
defenses.legal_basis: FCRA damages provisions, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681n, 1681o, require proof that noncompliance caused actual damages; failure of proof warrants summary judgment.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks admissible evidence of actual damages, including emotional distress
defenses.legal_basis: Under 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681n, 1681o, recovery requires competent evidence of actual damages; speculative or unsupported emotional distress is insufficient.

defenses.defense: AI-generated phone call transcript offered by plaintiff is unreliable and inadmissible evidence
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Evidence regarding authentication and reliability of evidence (including hearsay and foundation requirements); court excluded the AI-generated transcript and any arguments relying on it.

case_name: Civic v. Quintus Corporation et al.

case_id: 2016-04-06_USCOURTS-moed-4_15-md-02669_IN RE_ ASHLEY MADISON CUSTOMER DATA SECURITY BREACH LITIGATION.pdf
case_name: In re Ashley Madison Customer Data Security Breach Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendants allegedly used automated chatbots to mimic real users on the dating platform, raising issues about deceptive AI-like automated systems in addition to the data breach.

claims.claim: Failure to adequately secure users’ personal and financial data, resulting in a large-scale data breach exposing Ashley Madison customers’ identities and information.
claims.legal_basis: Negligence and related data security duties under common law and consumer protection statutes (exact statutes vary by jurisdiction).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; the court addressed only whether named plaintiffs could proceed under pseudonyms as class representatives.

claims.claim: Use of automated bots to mimic real users on the Ashley Madison website, allegedly deceiving customers about the authenticity of interactions and the nature of the service.
claims.legal_basis: Consumer protection and fraud/misrepresentation theories under state statutes and common law (exact provisions not decided in this order).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; referenced as part of the factual background of the litigation.

claims.claim: Request by named plaintiffs to proceed under pseudonyms while serving as class representatives in the class action litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable request under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 10(a) and the court’s inherent authority to allow pseudonymous litigation in exceptional circumstances.
claims.outcome: Denied. The court held that plaintiffs may not serve as class representatives under pseudonyms because class members are entitled to know and evaluate their representatives, and transparency and accountability outweigh the privacy concerns in that representative role.

defenses.defense: Class representatives must be publicly identified so that absent class members and the court can assess their adequacy, credibility, and potential conflicts; pseudonymous representation undermines transparency and accountability in class actions.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 10(a) requiring naming of parties in the complaint, combined with class action adequacy and typicality requirements under Rule 23 and case law limiting pseudonymous litigation to exceptional circumstances.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ privacy and embarrassment concerns, while significant, do not constitute the kind of extraordinary threat (such as risk of physical harm or severe retaliation) that justifies pseudonymous litigation for class representatives.
defenses.legal_basis: Balancing test from federal precedent on pseudonymous litigation, which permits anonymity only in rare cases involving highly sensitive matters and serious risk of harm beyond mere embarrassment or reputational injury.

defenses.defense: Request that the federal court abstain in favor of the parallel state court action
defenses.legal_basis: Colorado River abstention doctrine, allowing federal courts to stay proceedings when there is a parallel state case involving the same parties and issues to promote judicial efficiency and avoid inconsistent rulings.

case_name: Lamont v. Conner et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged misappropriation of AI software designs and innovative AI solutions; plaintiff claimed defendants used his AI-related product concepts without authorization, though the court found no substantiated link between his AI ideas and Google Ventures’ activities.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets relating to software product designs and innovative AI solutions
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as to the Conner Defendants and Catherine Stephanie Straggas for lack of personal jurisdiction; dismissed without prejudice as to Google Ventures for failure to plead sufficient factual detail, with leave to amend the complaint against Google Ventures.

defenses.defense: Court lacks personal jurisdiction over the Conner Defendants and Catherine Stephanie Straggas
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; federal and state personal jurisdiction standards

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a plausible claim for trade secret misappropriation against Google Ventures
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) requiring sufficient factual allegations to state a claim under the Defend Trade Secrets Act

case_id: 2022-03-23_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Clearview’s facial recognition AI system built from scraped online images, alleged to violate privacy and free speech rights when used by municipal entities.

claims.claim: Improper creation and use of a facial recognition database from scraped online images without consent, violating privacy rights under the California Constitution
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution privacy protections; state constitutional right to privacy
claims.outcome: Court did not reach merits; held there was a reasonable possibility plaintiffs could succeed against municipal defendants, supporting remand to state court under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e).

claims.claim: Violation of free speech rights under the California Constitution through the collection and use of facial images in Clearview’s database
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution free speech protections
claims.outcome: Court did not reach merits; found claims against municipal defendants were at least potentially viable, defeating fraudulent joinder arguments and supporting remand to state court.

claims.claim: Liability of municipal defendants for using Clearview’s facial recognition database created from scraped images without consent, thereby participating in privacy and constitutional violations
claims.legal_basis: California constitutional privacy and free speech provisions; state-law theories of municipal liability
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiffs had a reasonable possibility of succeeding on these claims; rejected arguments that municipal defendants were sham or fraudulently joined and remanded the case to state court under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e).

defenses.defense: Nondiverse municipal defendants were fraudulently joined solely to defeat federal diversity jurisdiction
defenses.legal_basis: Federal removal and diversity jurisdiction doctrines; fraudulent joinder standard under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1332, 1441, and 1447(e)
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found plaintiffs had a reasonable possibility of success against municipal defendants, so joinder was not fraudulent and remand was appropriate.

defenses.defense: Claims against municipal defendants should be severed so that claims against Clearview AI remain in federal court
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e) and discretionary severance/remand principles
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court denied request to sever and instead remanded the entire action to state court.

case_name: Jones v. Google LLC, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged Google misrepresented itself as an artificial intelligence research company, but the AI-related characterization was incidental and not central to the legal analysis or holding.

claims.claim: Violation of the Kansas Consumer Protection Act based on loss of access to Google Plus web address and various Google services after shutdown of Google Plus
claims.legal_basis: Kansas Consumer Protection Act (KCPA), Kan. Stat. Ann. § 50-623 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; allegations lacked required specificity regarding any deceptive act, false representation, or defined consumer transaction.

claims.claim: KCPA claim premised on alleged false or misleading representations about Google’s status or activities, including being an artificial intelligence research company
claims.legal_basis: Kansas Consumer Protection Act (KCPA), Kan. Stat. Ann. § 50-626 (deceptive acts and practices)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to plead with particularity; plaintiff did not specify the time, place, or content of any misrepresentation or how it caused his loss.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim under the KCPA because it does not allege a specific deceptive act, misrepresentation, or defined consumer transaction with sufficient detail
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); pleading standards under Twombly and Iqbal; KCPA requirements for alleging deceptive acts

defenses.defense: Allegations of misrepresentation, including references to Google as an artificial intelligence research company, are conclusory and lack the required specificity as to time, place, and content
defenses.legal_basis: Heightened specificity requirements for fraud-like allegations under federal pleading standards applied to KCPA deceptive practices claims

case_name: Naughton v. Amazon.com, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged use of facial recognition and automated biometric systems to scan and collect employees’ facial geometry during wellness checks without consent.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) – unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and information (facial geometry) from employees during wellness checks without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b) (requirements for informed written consent before collecting biometric identifiers or information).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged that Amazon collected biometric data in violation of BIPA and allowed the claim to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) – unlawful possession and retention of employees’ biometric identifiers and information without a publicly available retention schedule or destruction guidelines.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a) (duty to develop and make public a written retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers and information).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged that Amazon possessed biometric data without a compliant retention and destruction policy and allowed the claim to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) – unlawful disclosure or dissemination of employees’ biometric identifiers and information to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d) (prohibition on disclosure or dissemination of biometric identifiers or information without consent or statutory authorization).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiff plausibly alleged that Amazon may have disclosed or disseminated biometric data without consent and allowed the claim to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) – unlawful profiting from employees’ biometric identifiers and information, if Amazon derived benefit from the biometric system.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c) (prohibition on selling, leasing, trading, or otherwise profiting from biometric identifiers or information).
claims.outcome: To the extent alleged, the court treated the complaint as plausibly stating BIPA violations overall and denied the motion to dismiss, allowing any such profit-based BIPA theory to proceed at the pleading stage.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because the wellness-check facial scans did not involve “biometric identifiers” or “biometric information” covered by BIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); statutory interpretation of 740 ILCS 14/10 definitions of “biometric identifier” and “biometric information.”

defenses.defense: Plaintiff consented to or voluntarily participated in the wellness checks, so any collection of facial data was authorized.
defenses.legal_basis: Implied or express consent principles under Illinois law; interpretation of BIPA’s informed consent requirements (740 ILCS 14/15(b)).

defenses.defense: BIPA does not apply to the alleged conduct because the wellness checks were for health/safety or employment-related purposes, falling outside the statute’s intended scope or within exemptions.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of BIPA scope and exemptions under 740 ILCS 14/10 and 14/25; argument that employment or health-screening uses are not covered or are preempted by other regimes.

defenses.defense: Lack of concrete injury or standing, arguing that any technical BIPA violation did not cause real harm to plaintiff or the class.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution; case law on informational and privacy injuries in BIPA cases.

defenses.defense: Preemption or conflict with other laws governing workplace health screenings or employment practices, limiting BIPA’s application.
defenses.legal_basis: Preemption doctrines and interaction between BIPA and other state or federal employment/health regulations.

case_id: 2022-07-25_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI facial-recognition algorithms on scraped images, allegedly creating biometric identifiers without consent, which is central to the privacy and BIPA claims.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and biometric information from Illinois residents without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Claim remains pending; court denied defendants’ reconsideration arguments challenging personal jurisdiction and Article III standing as waived, so the BIPA §15(b) theory continues forward.
