claims.claim: Unlawful capture and use of facial geometry through AI-based facial recognition on images scraped from the internet
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a), 14/15(c), and/or related provisions (retention, disclosure, and profit restrictions)
claims.outcome: Claims remain pending; court rejected reconsideration arguments that attempted to re-raise or newly raise challenges to the sufficiency of BIPA claims, treating those arguments as waived.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of Illinois residents whose biometric data was allegedly collected and used without compliance with BIPA
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism)
claims.outcome: Class claims remain in the case; the court’s order did not dismiss or narrow the class allegations and instead left prior rulings intact while denying reconsideration.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over certain defendants, including challenges to the court’s authority to adjudicate claims against them
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; federal personal-jurisdiction doctrine
defenses.outcome: Court held that defendants had waived further personal-jurisdiction arguments by not adequately developing them earlier and therefore denied reconsideration on this ground.

defenses.defense: Lack of Article III standing because plaintiffs allegedly did not suffer a concrete injury from the alleged BIPA violations
defenses.legal_basis: Article III of the U.S. Constitution; federal standing jurisprudence (e.g., Spokeo and progeny)
defenses.outcome: Court ruled that any new or renewed standing arguments were waived because they were not properly presented before; motion for reconsideration on standing was denied and prior standing rulings remain in effect.

defenses.defense: Government-contractor exemption under BIPA, arguing that Clearview’s activities were exempt because it provided services to government or law-enforcement clients
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) government-contractor exemption provision
defenses.outcome: Court found that defendants had not sufficiently developed this exemption argument earlier and treated new arguments on reconsideration as waived; motion for reconsideration on this exemption was denied.

defenses.defense: Argument that individual defendant Thomas Mulcaire should not remain a party to the case
defenses.legal_basis: Procedural and substantive defenses to individual liability (e.g., failure to state a claim or misjoinder)
defenses.outcome: Court clarified that Thomas Mulcaire remains a defendant in the lawsuit and rejected the attempt, via reconsideration, to remove him from the case.

case_name: Gutierrez v. Wemagine.AI LLP
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-powered photo-editing app collecting and storing facial biometric data without consent

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, capturing, and storing users’ facial geometry and biometric identifiers through the Voila AI Artist app without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over the defendant

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by failing to provide a publicly available written policy regarding retention and destruction of biometric data collected via the app
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over the defendant

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by disclosing or otherwise disseminating users’ biometric identifiers or information without proper consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over the defendant

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction because Wemagine.AI, a Canadian company, did not purposefully direct its business activities or marketing toward Illinois; any contacts with Illinois arose solely from users’ unilateral decision to download and use the app
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment

defenses.defense: Operation of a globally available mobile application, without Illinois-specific targeting, does not create sufficient minimum contacts to support specific jurisdiction in Illinois
defenses.legal_basis: Minimum contacts and purposeful availment standards for specific jurisdiction under U.S. Supreme Court and Seventh Circuit precedent

case_id: 2022-05-26_USCOURTS-flsd-1_21-cv-23472_Birmingham et al v. Rofx.net et al.pdf
case_name: Birmingham et al. v. RoFx.net et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged AI-powered forex trading platform used as part of fraudulent misrepresentations to investors.

claims.claim: Civil fraud and misrepresentation related to investments in the RoFx.net foreign exchange trading platform, which was marketed as using AI-powered trading algorithms to generate returns.
claims.legal_basis: State and/or federal fraud and misrepresentation laws (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Claim against ePayments Systems Ltd. dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction; claims against other defendants not resolved in this order.

claims.claim: Civil conspiracy to defraud investors through the RoFx.net scheme, including alleged participation by ePayments Systems Ltd. in processing or facilitating investor funds.
claims.legal_basis: Civil conspiracy principles under applicable state/federal law (specific provisions not identified in summary).
claims.outcome: Conspiracy-based claim against ePayments Systems Ltd. dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction because plaintiffs failed to show EPS was a co-conspirator with conduct purposefully directed at Florida or with a sufficient Florida nexus.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over ePayments Systems Ltd. because it is a UK-based entity with no purposeful availment of the Florida forum and no sufficient Florida-directed conduct related to the alleged scheme.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on personal jurisdiction under the U.S. Constitution and Florida’s long-arm statute.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court held it lacked personal jurisdiction over EPS and dismissed all claims against it.

defenses.defense: Insufficient factual allegations to establish that ePayments Systems Ltd. was part of a conspiracy with acts in or purposefully directed at Florida, or that any co-conspirator’s Florida conduct could be imputed to EPS for jurisdictional purposes.
defenses.legal_basis: Civil conspiracy jurisdictional doctrine requiring a prima facie showing of co-conspirator status and forum-related acts.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court found plaintiffs failed to establish EPS as a co-conspirator with a Florida nexus and therefore could not base personal jurisdiction on a conspiracy theory.

case_id: 2025-07-25_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_22-cv-00046_Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Defendants’ DriveCam system allegedly used machine vision and AI to detect distracted driving, collecting and storing drivers’ biometric data without consent, which formed the basis of the BIPA claims and the class action settlement.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of drivers’ biometric identifiers and biometric information through Lytx DriveCam systems without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) (informed written consent and disclosure requirements).
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court granted final approval and dismissed the action with prejudice in exchange for monetary relief from a $4.25 million settlement fund and related settlement terms.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and retention of drivers’ biometric data collected by AI-enabled DriveCam devices without a publicly available retention schedule and destruction policy.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) (retention schedule and destruction policy).
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court approved settlement as fair, reasonable, and adequate, with claims released and case dismissed with prejudice.

claims.claim: Unlawful disclosure or dissemination of drivers’ biometric data to third parties without proper consent or authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) (prohibition on disclosure without consent).
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; claims released in exchange for settlement benefits, and the action dismissed with prejudice.

defenses.defense: Denial of liability for any violation of BIPA, asserting that their conduct complied with applicable law and did not unlawfully collect, store, or use biometric data.
defenses.legal_basis: General denial of statutory violations under Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and related compliance arguments.

defenses.defense: Settlement entered without admission of wrongdoing or liability, maintaining that the settlement is a compromise to avoid the burden, expense, and uncertainty of continued litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard class action settlement principles under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 and contract/compromise doctrines.

case_name: Risher v. Adecco Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Use of AI chatbot “Mya” to send automated recruiting text messages allegedly in violation of TCPA.

claims.claim: Defendants sent unsolicited text messages using an automatic telephone dialing system (autodialer) in violation of the TCPA.
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) restrictions on use of an automatic telephone dialing system to call or text cell phones without prior consent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that the system used did not qualify as an autodialer under the narrowed definition consistent with Supreme Court precedent.

claims.claim: Defendants sent unsolicited text messages using an artificial or prerecorded voice in violation of the TCPA.
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) prohibition on calls to cell phones using an artificial or prerecorded voice without prior consent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that text messages, even if generated by an AI chatbot, do not constitute use of an “artificial or prerecorded voice” under the TCPA.

claims.claim: Class-action claim seeking to represent a class of individuals who received similar unsolicited recruiting text messages from defendants in violation of the TCPA.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 class action mechanism combined with alleged TCPA violations, 47 U.S.C. § 227.
claims.outcome: Effectively denied/dismissed as moot because the underlying TCPA claims were dismissed; no viable cause of action remained to support class certification.

defenses.defense: The messaging system used to send texts is not an automatic telephone dialing system under the TCPA as interpreted by the Supreme Court.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) and the Supreme Court’s narrowing of the autodialer definition (requiring use of a random or sequential number generator).

defenses.defense: Text messages generated by the AI chatbot do not involve an artificial or prerecorded voice, so the TCPA’s “artificial or prerecorded voice” provision does not apply.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of “voice” in 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A), limiting it to audible voice communications, not written text messages.

case_id: 2022-03-18_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Facial-recognition AI used to scrape online images, create biometric database, and identify individuals in surveillance footage, forming core of alleged BIPA violations.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection and use of biometric identifiers and information via Clearview AI’s facial-recognition database without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiffs adequately alleged a concrete BIPA injury; Macy’s interlocutory appeal on this issue was denied, so the claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Unlawful profiting from or otherwise benefiting from individuals’ biometric identifiers and information through Macy’s use of Clearview’s database for commercial purposes
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c)
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiffs plausibly alleged that Macy’s use of the database was for profit or commercial benefit; Macy’s request for interlocutory appeal on this issue was denied, and the claim continues.

claims.claim: General violation of biometric privacy rights by creating and using a massive facial-recognition database built from images scraped from the internet without notice or consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) overall statutory scheme; Article III standing doctrine for statutory privacy harms
claims.outcome: Court concluded plaintiffs sufficiently alleged concrete harm under BIPA consistent with prior precedent; no substantial ground for difference of opinion justified interlocutory appeal, so litigation proceeds in district court.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to allege a concrete injury sufficient for Article III standing for their BIPA claims
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution; 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b) as vehicle for interlocutory review

defenses.defense: The legal questions regarding what constitutes a concrete injury under BIPA and whether Macy’s conduct falls within BIPA’s scope are contestable and warrant immediate appellate review
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1292(b) standard for interlocutory appeal (controlling question of law, substantial ground for difference of opinion, and material advancement of litigation)

case_name: Gutierrez v. Wemagine.AI LLP
ai_relevance: AI-powered photo-editing app allegedly collected, stored, and disclosed biometric data without consent

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, capturing, or otherwise obtaining users’ biometric identifiers and information through the Voila AI Artist app without informed written consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach the merits of the alleged BIPA violations

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by storing and retaining users’ biometric identifiers and information without a publicly available retention schedule or destruction policy and beyond the period permitted by law
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach the merits of the alleged BIPA violations

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by disclosing, redisclosing, or otherwise disseminating users’ biometric identifiers and information to third parties without consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach the merits of the alleged BIPA violations

claims.claim: Class action claim seeking statutory damages, injunctive relief, and other remedies for all similarly situated Illinois users of the Voila AI Artist app
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/20; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23
claims.outcome: Putative class claims dismissed without prejudice because the court lacked personal jurisdiction over the defendant and therefore could not adjudicate class relief

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction because Wemagine.AI did not purposefully direct its activities at Illinois or specifically target the Illinois market, even though Illinois residents could download and use the app
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; federal personal-jurisdiction doctrine (minimum contacts and purposeful availment) applied in diversity/federal-question context
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court held it lacked personal jurisdiction and dismissed the case without prejudice

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ alleged injuries did not arise out of or relate to any Illinois-specific conduct by Wemagine.AI, but rather to general nationwide availability of the app
defenses.legal_basis: Specific personal jurisdiction ‘arise out of or relate to’ requirement under federal due process standards
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court found no Illinois-focused conduct connecting defendant’s actions to the forum and relied on this in dismissing for lack of personal jurisdiction

case_name: Trio v. Turing Video, Inc.
ai_relevance: AI-integrated temperature-screening kiosk allegedly captured and processed facial geometry without BIPA-compliant consent.

claims.claim: Unlawful collection of biometric identifiers and biometric information via Turing Shield facial-scanning temperature kiosks without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and retention of biometric identifiers and biometric information without a publicly available written retention schedule and destruction policy, and without following BIPA’s retention and destruction requirements.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Unlawful disclosure or dissemination of biometric identifiers and biometric information to third parties, including remote servers or vendors, without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Failure to protect biometric identifiers and biometric information using the reasonable standard of care and safeguards required for sensitive data.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(e)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Failure to obtain a written release and provide required written disclosures before collecting or capturing biometric identifiers and information from employees and other users of the Turing Shield device.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Turing Video because its contacts with Illinois are insufficient.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s BIPA claims are preempted by Section 301 of the Labor Management Relations Act because they require interpretation of a collective bargaining agreement.
defenses.legal_basis: Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA) § 301 preemption doctrine.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s claims are barred or preempted by the Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness Act due to the device’s role in COVID-19 screening and related immunity provisions.
defenses.legal_basis: Public Readiness and Emergency Preparedness (PREP) Act, 42 U.S.C. § 247d-6d.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a claim upon which relief can be granted because the alleged conduct does not fall within BIPA’s scope or requirements.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and statutory interpretation of BIPA.

case_name: Silva v. U.S. Army et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged use of AI-driven and automated wireless technology for torture and spoofing operations, claiming advanced technological systems were used to harm and surveil him.

claims.claim: Conspiracy by federal agencies and pharmaceutical companies to provide fake or fraudulent drugs to the plaintiff.
claims.legal_basis: Unclear tort and fraud theories asserted under federal-question jurisdiction; allegations framed as federal constitutional and statutory violations but pled in a vague and conclusory manner.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim; allegations deemed implausible, vague, and unsupported by specific facts.

claims.claim: Use of advanced wireless, AI-driven technology to torture, harass, and surveil the plaintiff remotely.
claims.legal_basis: Alleged violations of constitutional rights and unspecified federal laws based on supposed government and corporate misuse of advanced technology; pled as civil rights and conspiracy claims.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim; court found allegations conclusory, unfounded, and insufficient under plausibility standards.

claims.claim: Spoofing operations and technological manipulation targeting the plaintiff through automated or AI-based systems.
claims.legal_basis: Alleged unlawful surveillance, harassment, and technological interference under unspecified federal statutes and constitutional provisions.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim; court held that the complaint lacked concrete factual support and did not present a plausible legal theory.

claims.claim: General conspiracy among federal agencies and pharmaceutical companies to harm the plaintiff using fake drugs and advanced technology.
claims.legal_basis: Broad conspiracy and civil rights theories under federal law, asserted without specific statutory grounding or factual detail.
claims.outcome: Dismissed in full on motions to dismiss; court held that the conspiracy allegations were speculative, conclusory, and insufficient to invoke federal jurisdiction or survive Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: The court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over plaintiff’s claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(1); plaintiff failed to allege a non-frivolous federal question or any viable basis for federal jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); allegations were vague, conclusory, implausible, and unsupported by specific facts as required by Twombly/Iqbal standards.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations are fanciful and frivolous, and therefore cannot support federal jurisdiction or a cognizable claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Doctrine permitting dismissal of factually frivolous or delusional claims; application of plausibility and non-frivolousness requirements for federal-question jurisdiction.

case_name: Phi Theta Kappa Honor Society v. HonorSociety.org
ai_relevance: Generative AI allegedly used to create and disseminate misleading online content about a competing honor society, forming part of the factual basis for the dispute and the requested injunction.

claims.claim: Defendant disseminated false and misleading statements about plaintiff online, including at scale using generative AI, to divert prospective members and harm plaintiff’s reputation and business.
claims.legal_basis: False advertising and unfair competition under trademark/consumer protection principles (e.g., Lanham Act–type claims) and related state-law unfair competition.
claims.outcome: District court granted a preliminary injunction restricting defendant’s speech; on appeal, the Fifth Circuit vacated the preliminary injunction as an overbroad prior restraint and impermissible compelled speech in violation of the First Amendment, and remanded for further proceedings.

claims.claim: Defendant’s misleading online content and marketing practices caused confusion among students and schools about the relationship between the parties and the legitimacy of plaintiff’s organization.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition and likely confusion theories under trademark and consumer protection law.
claims.outcome: No final merits determination; preliminary injunctive relief based on this theory was vacated by the Court of Appeals and the case remanded.

defenses.defense: The injunction imposed by the district court was an overbroad prior restraint on speech and impermissibly compelled speech, violating the First Amendment.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment free speech protections against prior restraints and compelled speech; constitutional limits on injunctive relief regulating speech.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted by the Court of Appeals, which vacated the preliminary injunction and remanded.

defenses.defense: Disputed statements constitute protected speech or are not shown, at this stage, to be actionable false advertising warranting such broad injunctive relief.
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment protection for non-misleading or insufficiently proven commercial speech; standards for preliminary injunctions requiring clear evidence of falsity and harm.
defenses.defense_outcome: Partially accepted to the extent that the appellate court found the injunction unjustified and overbroad on the current record, leading to vacatur of the injunction, but no final ruling on ultimate liability.

case_id: 2020-12-07_USCOURTS-cand-5_20-mc-80141_In re Rule 45 Subpoenas Issued to Google LLC and LinkedIn Corporation Dated July 23_ 2020.pdf
case_name: In re Rule 45 Subpoenas Issued to Google LLC and LinkedIn Corporation Dated July 23, 2020
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on online criticism of Spider Labs’ claimed use of AI to detect ad fraud; anonymous speaker questioned effectiveness and truthfulness of those AI-technology claims, leading to subpoenas seeking the critic’s identity.

claims.claim: Defamation based on John Doe’s anonymous online statements criticizing Spider Labs and questioning the truthfulness and effectiveness of its claimed AI-based ad fraud detection technology.
claims.legal_basis: State defamation law (libel) asserted in underlying civil action; used as basis to seek discovery of Doe’s identity via Rule 45 subpoenas.
claims.outcome: Court found Spider Labs failed to present competent evidence establishing a prima facie case of defamation; without such showing, the First Amendment right to anonymous speech prevailed and the subpoenas were quashed.

claims.claim: Enforcement of Rule 45 subpoenas to Google LLC and LinkedIn Corporation to compel disclosure of John Doe’s identifying information for use in the defamation lawsuit.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45 governing subpoenas for documents and identifying information from third-party service providers.
claims.outcome: Court denied enforcement by granting Doe’s motion to quash; subpoenas to Google and LinkedIn were invalidated and could not be used to obtain Doe’s identity.

defenses.defense: First Amendment right to anonymous speech protects Doe’s identity absent a prima facie showing of defamation by Spider Labs.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, First Amendment; case law requiring a prima facie defamation showing before unmasking anonymous speakers.

defenses.defense: Spider Labs failed to establish a prima facie case of defamation because it did not provide competent evidence that Doe’s statements were false, defamatory, or caused cognizable harm.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive elements of defamation under applicable state law; evidentiary standards for prima facie showing in unmasking cases.

defenses.defense: Subpoenas are overbroad and improper because they seek identifying information without sufficient justification, imposing an undue burden on Doe’s First Amendment rights and on third-party providers.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45 (limits on subpoenas and undue burden) combined with constitutional protections for anonymous online speech.

case_id: 2020-12-21_USCOURTS-mied-2_17-cv-10657_Cahoo et al v. SAS Analytics Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Cahoo et al. v. SAS Analytics Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Automated fraud-detection system (MiDAS) allegedly misidentified unemployment fraud without due process; plaintiffs claim injuries traceable to design, implementation, and operation of this algorithmic system.

claims.claim: Procedural due process violations arising from automated fraud determinations in unemployment benefits (MiDAS) without adequate notice or opportunity to be heard.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause; brought via 42 U.S.C. § 1983.
claims.outcome: Court denied defendants’ motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, holding plaintiffs sufficiently alleged Article III standing; procedural due process claim against these defendants may proceed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because their alleged injuries are not fairly traceable to defendants’ conduct in developing or implementing MiDAS.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III case-or-controversy requirement; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(1) motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: Any injuries result from independent actions of the state unemployment agency, breaking the causal chain between MiDAS developers and plaintiffs’ harms.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III traceability and redressability requirements for standing; intervening acts of a third party (state agency).

case_name: Jones v. Douglas County Jail
ai_relevance: Petitioner alleged AI influenced his criminal and jail proceedings, but the court found these AI-related assertions unsupported and meritless, giving them no legal effect.

claims.claim: Unconstitutional delay in competency evaluations and related criminal proceedings while held as a pretrial detainee
claims.legal_basis: Sixth Amendment right to speedy trial; Fourteenth Amendment due process; asserted via federal habeas corpus (28 U.S.C. § 2241)
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held petitioner failed to exhaust available state court remedies and, in any event, did not adequately present a cognizable federal constitutional violation for habeas relief.

claims.claim: Unlawful pretrial detention and continued confinement in Douglas County Jail
claims.legal_basis: Fourteenth Amendment due process; Eighth Amendment-type conditions concerns, raised through federal habeas corpus
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found state remedies had not been exhausted and that the allegations were tied primarily to state-law issues not redressable in federal habeas at this stage.

claims.claim: Violations based on delays and procedures governed by Kansas state law regarding competency and criminal process
claims.legal_basis: Kansas state statutes and procedural rules governing competency evaluations and criminal case processing
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that alleged violations of state law alone are not grounds for federal habeas corpus relief.

claims.claim: Constitutional violations arising from alleged artificial intelligence (AI) intervention or influence in his criminal and jail matters
claims.legal_basis: Invoked generally under federal constitutional rights (Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments) without specific doctrinal basis
claims.outcome: Dismissed as meritless; court found no factual or legal support for the claim that AI intervention affected his cases or created a cognizable federal constitutional violation.

defenses.defense: Petitioner failed to exhaust available state court remedies before seeking federal habeas relief
defenses.legal_basis: Exhaustion requirement for state detainees seeking federal habeas corpus relief under 28 U.S.C. § 2241 and related precedent.

defenses.defense: Allegations concern only state-law errors, which are not grounds for federal habeas relief absent an independent federal constitutional violation
defenses.legal_basis: Limits of federal habeas jurisdiction; federal habeas relief lies only for violations of the Constitution, laws, or treaties of the United States.

defenses.defense: Petitioner failed to state a cognizable federal constitutional claim under the Sixth, Eighth, or Fourteenth Amendments
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive standards for federal constitutional claims in habeas corpus; requirement that petitioner allege specific, non-conclusory constitutional violations.

defenses.defense: Claims of AI intervention are conclusory and unsupported, and therefore legally insufficient
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards requiring factual support for constitutional claims; court’s authority to dismiss frivolous or factually baseless allegations in habeas proceedings.

case_name: Clark v. Microsoft Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-driven video coaching and Azure Cognitive Services analyzing facial expressions as alleged biometric data under BIPA.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(a) for possessing and controlling biometric identifiers/information without a publicly available retention schedule and destruction guidelines.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim plausibly alleged and allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(b) for collecting or otherwise obtaining biometric identifiers/information without informed written consent and required disclosures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to allege that Microsoft took active steps to collect or otherwise obtain biometric data; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(c) for profiting from or otherwise deriving value from biometric identifiers/information.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction due to lack of concrete personal harm from alleged profiting; dismissal with leave to amend jurisdictional allegations.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(d) for disclosing or disseminating biometric identifiers/information to third parties without consent or statutory authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to allege that Microsoft took active steps to disclose or disseminate biometric data; leave to amend granted.

defenses.defense: Microsoft did not actively collect or otherwise obtain biometric data, but merely provided cloud and AI services used by Brainshark, so it is not liable under BIPA §§ 15(b) and 15(d).
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of BIPA §§ 15(b), 15(d) requiring active collection/obtaining or dissemination by the defendant.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks Article III standing for the § 15(c) claim because he did not allege a concrete, personal injury from Microsoft’s alleged profiting from biometric data.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; federal subject-matter jurisdiction principles.

defenses.defense: Any alleged possession or control of biometric data by Microsoft is insufficiently pled to establish a BIPA violation.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and interpretation of BIPA § 15(a).

case_id: 2024-04-18_USCOURTS-ca10-22-01402_Underwood_ et al v. Bank of America Corporation.pdf
case_name: Underwood et al. v. Bank of America Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI virtual assistant trademarks; both parties’ marks used for automated, AI-driven financial assistant services.

claims.claim: Federal trademark infringement based on Bank of America’s use of the ERICA mark allegedly infringing plaintiffs’ unregistered E.R.I.C.A. service mark for a virtual assistant.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 32 and/or § 43(a) (15 U.S.C. §§ 1114, 1125(a)) for infringement of an unregistered service mark through prior actual use in commerce.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Bank of America; court held plaintiffs lacked a protectable interest in the E.R.I.C.A. mark because they failed to show actual use in commerce that clearly distinguished and identified their services, so the infringement claim failed as a matter of law.

claims.claim: Federal unfair competition and false designation of origin based on Bank of America’s use of ERICA allegedly causing confusion with plaintiffs’ E.R.I.C.A. mark.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) (15 U.S.C. § 1125(a)) for unfair competition and false designation of origin.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Bank of America; without a protectable interest in the E.R.I.C.A. mark, plaintiffs’ unfair competition and false designation claims could not succeed.

claims.claim: Related state-law trademark and unfair competition claims premised on alleged rights in the E.R.I.C.A. mark and confusion caused by Bank of America’s ERICA assistant.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law trademark infringement and unfair competition (following similar standards to federal Lanham Act claims).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for Bank of America; state-law claims failed because plaintiffs did not establish a valid, protectable mark through actual use in commerce.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack a protectable interest in the E.R.I.C.A. mark because they did not actually use it in commerce in a way that clearly distinguished and identified their services.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act requirement of prior actual use in commerce to establish rights in an unregistered mark; trademark common-law principles on protectable interest.

defenses.defense: Without a valid, protectable mark, there can be no likelihood of confusion or liability for trademark infringement or unfair competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of federal and state trademark infringement and unfair competition claims requiring a valid mark as a threshold issue.

case_name: Gjovik v. Apple Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff used generative AI to draft filings; court warned about inaccuracies and emphasized attorney/party duty to verify AI-generated legal content.

claims.claim: Motion to strike Apple’s affirmative defenses as insufficient, improper, or inadequately pleaded.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(f) and related pleading standards for affirmative defenses.
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; some affirmative defenses were stricken with leave to amend, others were allowed to stand.

claims.claim: Motion for a more definite statement regarding Apple’s responses and affirmative defenses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(e).
claims.outcome: Denied in full; the court held Rule 12(e) was procedurally inapplicable to the challenged filings and that Apple’s responses were sufficiently clear.

defenses.defense: Multiple affirmative defenses to plaintiff’s underlying employment-related claims (e.g., generic boilerplate defenses such as failure to state a claim, statute of limitations, waiver, estoppel, and similar defenses).
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8(c) and substantive employment and procedural law supporting each asserted affirmative defense.
defenses.defense_outcome: Some defenses were found inadequately pleaded and stricken with leave to amend; others were deemed sufficiently stated and allowed to remain.

defenses.defense: Opposition to motion for more definite statement, arguing that its existing answers and defenses were sufficiently clear and that Rule 12(e) did not apply to the challenged documents.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(e) and case law limiting its use to vague or ambiguous pleadings requiring clarification before a responsive pleading.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court denied the motion for a more definite statement and left Apple’s existing responses in place.

case_name: Dopp v. Wray et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged harm from implanted chip using AI and radio-frequency technologies to cause psychological and physical injury.

claims.claim: Defendants implanted a chip in plaintiff’s body and used it to cause psychological and physical harm through radio frequencies and AI-driven technologies.
claims.legal_basis: Civil rights and personal injury claims under federal law (treated as constitutional and tort-type allegations).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as frivolous for lacking any factual or legal basis.

claims.claim: Defendants used AI and radio-frequency technologies to control or manipulate plaintiff’s thoughts, perceptions, and behavior, violating his constitutional rights.
claims.legal_basis: Implied constitutional and civil rights violations (e.g., due process, bodily integrity, freedom from cruel or unusual treatment).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as frivolous for lacking any factual or legal basis.

claims.claim: Request to proceed without prepaying court fees (in forma pauperis) based on indigence.
claims.legal_basis: Application under in forma pauperis statute allowing waiver of filing fees for indigent litigants with non-frivolous claims.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the underlying complaint was dismissed as frivolous.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations about implanted chip, AI, and radio-frequency harm are fantastical and lack any plausible factual support.
defenses.legal_basis: Screening standard for in forma pauperis complaints; court’s authority to dismiss frivolous or delusional claims under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B).

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state any cognizable legal claim under federal law despite references to harm and constitutional violations.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted under federal pleading standards (Rule 8/Rule 12(b)(6)-type analysis).

case_name: Stein v. Clarifai, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used AI-based facial recognition to extract and analyze biometric data from online photos without consent, leading to BIPA and unjust enrichment claims.

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for collecting, capturing, and using biometric identifiers and biometric information from plaintiff’s OKCupid photographs without informed written consent and without required disclosures or retention policies.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over defendant; court did not reach the merits of the BIPA claim.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on Clarifai’s alleged benefit from using plaintiff’s and class members’ biometric data and photographs to develop and improve its facial recognition technology without compensation or authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois common law of unjust enrichment.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over defendant; court did not reach the merits of the unjust enrichment claim.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Clarifai in Illinois because Clarifai’s contacts with the state are insufficient to establish specific or general jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process and minimum contacts doctrine under the Fourteenth Amendment; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Any alleged contacts with Illinois, including limited sales of Clarifai’s demographic model to a small number of Illinois customers, are too minimal and not sufficiently related to plaintiff’s claims to support specific jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Specific personal jurisdiction standards under federal due process and Illinois long-arm statute (coextensive with federal due process).

case_name: Goins v. Father Flanagan's Boys' Home
ai_relevance: Plaintiff allegedly used generative AI to draft briefing that contained inaccurate legal citations, which the defendant highlighted; AI use contributed to briefing deficiencies but was not itself the legal claim.

claims.claim: Sex discrimination in employment (including termination)
claims.legal_basis: Federal employment discrimination law (likely Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; court found the complaint lacked sufficient factual allegations to support sex discrimination, was untimely in part, and contained no evidence of discriminatory bias or intent.

claims.claim: Retaliation for filing discrimination charges
claims.legal_basis: Federal employment retaliation provisions (likely Title VII anti-retaliation)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; court held plaintiff did not allege specific protected activity, causal connection, or supporting facts, and some allegations were procedurally barred or untimely.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and substantive standards for Title VII discrimination and retaliation claims requiring plausible factual allegations.

defenses.defense: Untimely and procedurally barred claims
defenses.legal_basis: Title VII administrative exhaustion and limitations requirements, including deadlines for filing EEOC charges and bringing suit after right-to-sue notice.

defenses.defense: Lack of evidence of discriminatory or retaliatory intent
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive burden under federal employment discrimination and retaliation law requiring proof of discriminatory motive or causal connection, which the court found lacking.

defenses.defense: Unreliable and inaccurate briefing allegedly generated by AI
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority to require accurate citations and competent advocacy; argument that plaintiff’s reliance on generative AI led to inaccurate citations and unsupported assertions, undermining his claims.

case_id: 2025-03-26_USCOURTS-deb-1_23-ap-50370_Ryniker et al v. Washington et al.pdf
case_name: Ryniker et al. v. Washington et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from failed funding of Augustus Intelligence, an AI solutions company, whose business centered on artificial intelligence technologies.

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on Seed Agreement requiring defendant to provide a $50 million investment to Augustus Intelligence, Inc.
claims.legal_basis: State-law breach of contract under the Seed Agreement between Augustus Intelligence, Inc. and Kevin Washington
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held the Seed Agreement was unenforceable because it was part of a fraudulent scheme to induce other investors, so no enforceable contractual obligation could be enforced against Washington.

claims.claim: Assigned Investor Claims seeking to recover on third-party investor rights allegedly assigned to the Litigation Trustee against Washington and related parties
claims.legal_basis: State-law contract and related claims assigned by certain investors to the Litigation Trustee, asserted under bankruptcy court’s post-confirmation jurisdiction
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction; court held these were third-party, non-estate claims insufficiently related to the bankruptcy case post-confirmation, so the bankruptcy court lacked jurisdiction to adjudicate them.

defenses.defense: The Seed Agreement is unenforceable because it was part of a fraudulent scheme to defraud investors and therefore cannot support a breach of contract claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law doctrine that courts will not enforce contracts founded on fraud, illegality, or used as instruments of fraud (void or unenforceable as against public policy).

defenses.defense: Bankruptcy court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over Assigned Investor Claims because they are third-party, non-estate claims asserted post-confirmation and do not have a close nexus to the bankruptcy plan.
defenses.legal_basis: Limits on bankruptcy jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1334 and 157 and post-confirmation “close nexus” requirement for related-to jurisdiction.

case_id: 2020-10-23_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_20-cv-03843_Thornley et al v. Clearview AI_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Thornley et al. v. Clearview AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI-driven facial recognition to scrape online images, create biometric identifiers, and build a searchable face-recognition database that allegedly violated BIPA.

claims.claim: Unlawful profiting from biometric identifiers and biometric information without consent
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c) (prohibition on profiting from biometric data)
claims.outcome: No merits ruling in federal court; case remanded to Illinois state court for lack of Article III standing because plaintiffs alleged only statutory damages and fees, not a concrete injury-in-fact.

claims.claim: Class-wide statutory damages and attorneys’ fees for Clearview’s alleged sale and monetization of plaintiffs’ biometric data
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) remedies provision, 740 ILCS 14/20
claims.outcome: No merits ruling in federal court; request for statutory damages and fees left for state court after remand due to lack of federal subject matter jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they alleged only a bare statutory violation and sought statutory damages and attorneys’ fees, without pleading any concrete, particularized injury-in-fact.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins and related federal standing jurisprudence.

defenses.defense: Federal subject matter jurisdiction exists under Article III and the Class Action Fairness Act (CAFA) because the alleged BIPA violations and requested statutory damages constitute a concrete injury.
defenses.legal_basis: Class Action Fairness Act (28 U.S.C. § 1332(d)) and federal standing doctrine under Article III.

case_name: Hodge v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged sexual assault by artificial intelligence; court found allegation unsupported and outside FTCA scope.

claims.claim: Tort claim under the Federal Tort Claims Act based on alleged sexual assault by artificial intelligence while plaintiff was a state pretrial detainee.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA), 28 U.S.C. §§ 1346(b), 2671–2680
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction because the United States retained sovereign immunity; allegations did not fall within FTCA’s waiver and did not identify negligent or wrongful acts by a federal employee acting within scope of employment; also found to fail to state a claim.

claims.claim: Tort/constitutional-type claim for denial of access to legal materials while in pretrial detention, asserted against the United States under the FTCA.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA), 28 U.S.C. §§ 1346(b), 2671–2680 (misused as vehicle for access-to-courts type grievance)
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and failure to state a claim because plaintiff did not allege actionable negligence by a federal employee and the claim did not fit within the FTCA’s limited waiver of sovereign immunity.

claims.claim: Appeal of district court’s dismissal of FTCA complaint and request to proceed in forma pauperis on appeal.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915 (in forma pauperis); appellate review standards for dismissal for lack of jurisdiction and failure to state a claim
claims.outcome: Tenth Circuit affirmed the district court’s dismissal, deemed the appeal frivolous, and denied the motion to proceed in forma pauperis on appeal.

defenses.defense: Sovereign immunity bars suit because plaintiff’s allegations do not fall within the FTCA’s limited waiver of immunity.
defenses.legal_basis: Sovereign immunity of the United States; FTCA waiver limited to certain torts by federal employees acting within scope of employment, 28 U.S.C. § 1346(b).

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim due to lack of specific factual allegations tying any negligent or wrongful act to a federal employee acting within the scope of employment.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s appeal is frivolous and therefore he should not be allowed to proceed in forma pauperis.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(a)(3) and (e)(2) (denial of in forma pauperis status and dismissal of frivolous appeals).

case_id: 2024-01-17_USCOURTS-ohsd-3_23-cv-00028_McComb v. Best Buy Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: McComb v. Best Buy Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Court expressly barred use of AI tools in drafting filings and required plaintiff to file an affidavit confirming no AI assistance was used, but AI is not part of the underlying discrimination dispute.

claims.claim: Racial discrimination in employment or services by Best Buy against the plaintiff
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state anti-discrimination laws prohibiting race discrimination (e.g., Title VII or analogous state statutes)
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided; court found the amended complaint failed to meet Rule 8(a) pleading standards and granted plaintiff leave to file a second amended complaint that is short and plain.

claims.claim: Disability discrimination in employment or services by Best Buy against the plaintiff
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state disability discrimination laws (e.g., Americans with Disabilities Act or analogous state statutes)
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided; court found the amended complaint failed to meet Rule 8(a) pleading standards and granted plaintiff leave to file a second amended complaint that is short and plain.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim and does not comply with basic pleading requirements because it is overly long, confusing, and not a short and plain statement
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8(a) and 12(b)(6) (motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim)
defenses.defense_outcome: Court agreed the pleading was deficient under Rule 8(a) but, instead of dismissing with prejudice, granted plaintiff leave to file a second amended complaint and denied defendants’ motion to dismiss without prejudice.

case_name: In re Pinterest Derivative Litigation
ai_relevance: Settlement required Pinterest to use AI tools to promote diverse and inclusive content representation on its platform, and the court evaluated compliance with these AI-driven diversity initiatives when awarding attorney’s fees.

claims.claim: Derivative claim that Pinterest’s directors and officers allowed or engaged in systemic race and sex discrimination in employment and corporate culture, harming the company and its shareholders.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law fiduciary duty principles (duty of loyalty, good faith, and oversight) underlying shareholder derivative actions.
claims.outcome: Resolved by settlement requiring governance, workplace, and content-diversity reforms, including AI-based diversity initiatives; court later found substantial compliance with these terms.

claims.claim: Request for court approval of a negotiated settlement that imposed diversity, equity, and inclusion reforms and monitoring obligations on Pinterest.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23.1 and applicable derivative-settlement approval standards (fairness, adequacy, and reasonableness to the corporation).
claims.outcome: Settlement previously approved; in the referenced order the court confirmed Pinterest’s substantial compliance and continued implementation of the agreed reforms.

claims.claim: Motion for attorney’s fees for plaintiffs’ counsel for monitoring Pinterest’s compliance with the settlement’s diversity and inclusivity reforms, including AI-related initiatives.
claims.legal_basis: Common-benefit doctrine in derivative litigation and the fee provisions in the court-approved settlement agreement.
claims.outcome: Court granted the motion and awarded $2,500,000 in attorney’s fees based on Pinterest’s substantial compliance and the benefits conferred by the reforms.

defenses.defense: Pinterest asserted that it had substantially complied with the settlement obligations, including implementing diversity, equity, and inclusion reforms and AI-supported content-diversity measures, so that any additional or larger fee award or further enforcement was unwarranted.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract and settlement-interpretation principles governing compliance with court-approved derivative settlements.

case_name: Virtual Radiologic Corporation v. Rabern
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete agreement
claims.legal_basis: Employment contract restrictive covenant under Minnesota contract law
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff unlikely to succeed on the merits and denied preliminary injunction; no injunctive relief granted on this claim.

claims.claim: Breach of non-solicitation agreement
claims.legal_basis: Employment contract restrictive covenant under Minnesota contract law
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff unlikely to succeed on the merits and denied preliminary injunction; no injunctive relief granted on this claim.

claims.claim: Breach of confidentiality / non-disclosure obligations
claims.legal_basis: Confidentiality provisions in employment agreement under Minnesota contract law
claims.outcome: Court held evidence insufficient to show likely breach or irreparable harm; denied preliminary injunction on this basis.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (including alleged misappropriation of confidential and proprietary business information)
claims.outcome: Court found insufficient evidence of misappropriation or threat of irreparable harm; denied preliminary injunction on this claim.

claims.claim: Fraud / misrepresentation regarding competitor’s business activities
claims.legal_basis: Common-law fraud and misrepresentation principles under Minnesota law, based on alleged false statements about Nines’ competitive status to induce contract modification
claims.outcome: Court concluded plaintiff had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits; no preliminary injunction issued based on alleged fraud or misrepresentation.

defenses.defense: No breach of non-compete or non-solicitation
defenses.legal_basis: Employee’s work for Nines allegedly outside scope of contractual restrictions and not directly competitive as claimed by plaintiff.

defenses.defense: No misappropriation of trade secrets or confidential information
defenses.legal_basis: Lack of evidence that defendant took, used, or disclosed plaintiff’s trade secrets or confidential information in his role at Nines.

defenses.defense: No fraud or intentional misrepresentation
defenses.legal_basis: Defendant’s statements about Nines’ business were not knowingly false or materially misleading, and plaintiff could not show justifiable reliance or resulting harm.

defenses.defense: Lack of irreparable harm to plaintiff
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standard for preliminary injunction; plaintiff failed to show non-compensable, imminent harm warranting injunctive relief.

defenses.defense: Failure to satisfy likelihood-of-success requirement for injunction
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard under federal law (Dataphase factors); plaintiff did not demonstrate probable success on any asserted claim.

case_name: Long, M.D., et al. v. Facebook, Inc.
ai_relevance: AI or automated systems (scraping and neural network software) were alleged as tools Facebook could use to detect infringing material, but the court held this did not establish Facebook’s actual knowledge of specific infringements.

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law, including secondary liability principles under the Copyright Act and interaction with DMCA safe harbor provisions
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held plaintiffs failed to plausibly allege Facebook’s actual knowledge of specific infringing material or that Facebook materially contributed with such knowledge, and Facebook remained protected by DMCA safe harbor.

defenses.defense: Lack of actual knowledge of specific infringing content
defenses.legal_basis: Contributory copyright infringement doctrine requiring actual knowledge of specific infringements; plaintiffs’ allegations and communications did not show Facebook knew of particular infringing posts on its platform.

defenses.defense: DMCA safe harbor protection for online service providers
defenses.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. § 512) limiting liability of service providers that act expeditiously to remove or disable access to infringing material upon proper notice; court found Facebook qualified and remained within the safe harbor.

case_id: 2025-08-26_USCOURTS-dcd-1_25-cv-01567_CATALDO v. UNITED STATES OF AMERICA et al.pdf
case_name: Cataldo v. United States of America et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff challenges risks from advanced AI systems developed and deployed by technology companies and government actors.

claims.claim: General challenge to development and deployment of advanced artificial intelligence systems by the federal government and technology companies, alleging broad, speculative future harms to society and to the plaintiff personally.
claims.legal_basis: Not clearly articulated; no specific statutory, constitutional, or common-law cause of action identified; treated as a putative civil action under federal-question jurisdiction and screened under 28 U.S.C. § 1915.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as frivolous under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i) for lack of a cognizable legal theory and reliance on fantastical, speculative allegations.

claims.claim: Application to proceed in forma pauperis to avoid paying filing fees based on alleged financial inability.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(a) (request to proceed without prepayment of fees).
claims.outcome: Denied because the plaintiff failed to provide sufficient, credible financial information and because the underlying complaint was deemed frivolous under 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i).

defenses.defense: The complaint is frivolous and based on fantastical, speculative fears about advanced AI, without concrete facts or a cognizable legal claim.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1915(e)(2)(B)(i) (mandatory dismissal of frivolous in forma pauperis actions).

defenses.defense: Failure to state any specific legal cause of action or identify a valid jurisdictional basis beyond generalized concerns about AI.
defenses.legal_basis: Implicit application of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6) standards through § 1915 screening (insufficient factual matter and no plausible claim).

case_name: Deyerler v. HireVue Inc.
ai_relevance: AI-powered video interview software allegedly captured and analyzed applicants’ biometric data in violation of BIPA.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(a) – failure to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written policy for retention and destruction of biometric identifiers and information collected from Illinois job applicants using HireVue’s AI interview software.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(b) – collection, capture, or obtaining of biometric identifiers and/or biometric information from Illinois job applicants without providing required written notice and obtaining informed written consent before using HireVue’s AI interview software.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(c) – profiting from, or otherwise deriving profit from, Illinois applicants’ biometric identifiers and information collected through HireVue’s AI interview platform.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; § 15(c) claim dismissed for failure to adequately allege that HireVue profited from the biometric data itself or that plaintiffs suffered individualized harm from such profit.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(d) – disclosure or dissemination of biometric identifiers or information to third parties in connection with HireVue’s AI interview services without meeting statutory conditions.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA § 15(e) – failure to use reasonable care in storing, transmitting, and protecting biometric identifiers and information collected via HireVue’s AI interview system.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(e).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Class action claim seeking statutory damages, injunctive relief, and other remedies for all similarly situated Illinois residents whose biometric data was collected or used through HireVue’s AI interview platform.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/20; class action procedure under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23.
claims.outcome: Case allowed to proceed past motion to dismiss stage, except as to the dismissed § 15(c) claim.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction – HireVue argued that the Illinois federal court lacked specific personal jurisdiction because HireVue is not based in Illinois and its conduct was not sufficiently directed at Illinois.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment; specific jurisdiction standards (purposeful availment and relatedness).
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found specific personal jurisdiction because HireVue purposefully availed itself of the Illinois market by providing its AI interview software to an Illinois-based employer and the claims arose from that conduct.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim under BIPA § 15(c) – HireVue argued that plaintiffs did not plausibly allege that HireVue sold, leased, traded, or otherwise profited from their biometric identifiers or information, as opposed to merely charging for software services.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); interpretation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act § 15(c).
defenses.outcome: Accepted in part; court granted motion to dismiss the § 15(c) claim for insufficient allegations of direct profit from biometric data or individualized harm.

defenses.defense: General failure to state a claim under other BIPA provisions – HireVue argued that plaintiffs’ allegations under §§ 15(a), 15(b), 15(d), and 15(e) were insufficiently pled or did not fall within the statute’s scope.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); statutory interpretation of BIPA §§ 15(a), 15(b), 15(d), and 15(e).
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court held that plaintiffs plausibly alleged violations of these BIPA provisions, allowing those claims to proceed.

case_id: 2025-10-08_USCOURTS-nmd-1_23-cv-00899_Lipe v. Albuquerque Public Schools et al.pdf
case_name: Lipe v. Albuquerque Public Schools et al.
ai_relevance: Court addressed plaintiff’s counsel’s use of generative AI to draft filings and cautioned that AI-generated content must be carefully reviewed to ensure accurate, warranted legal contentions and compliance with professional standards.

claims.claim: Request to deny or oppose Albuquerque Public Schools’ motion for a 10-day extension to provide supplemental discovery responses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure standards for discovery deadlines and extensions; argument that delay would cause prejudice and was not supported by good cause.
claims.outcome: Denied. The court found good cause for the extension, no bad faith by the school district, and granted the requested 10-day extension to supplement discovery responses.

defenses.defense: Request for a 10-day extension of time to serve supplemental discovery responses due to unforeseen circumstances affecting defense counsel’s law clerk.
defenses.legal_basis: Good-cause standard for modifying discovery deadlines under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 16(b)(4) and related discretion to extend time under Rule 6(b).

defenses.defense: Assertion that the requested extension would not prejudice the plaintiff and was not sought in bad faith.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable considerations in granting extensions under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, including absence of prejudice and bad faith.

case_id: 2025-09-08_USCOURTS-mnd-0_23-cv-03514_Estate of Gene B. Lokken_ The et al v. UnitedHealth Group_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Estate of Gene B. Lokken et al. v. UnitedHealth Group, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege defendants used an AI-driven tool, nH Predict, instead of human medical directors to make or drive coverage-denial decisions, breaching insurance contracts and obligations to provide human medical review.

claims.claim: Breach of insurance contracts by using nH Predict instead of promised human medical directors to make coverage determinations and deny or limit benefits.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing health insurance policies and plan documents promising physician or human medical director review of coverage decisions.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this stage; court’s order only denies defendants’ motion to bifurcate discovery, and the breach-of-contract claim proceeds to unified discovery.

claims.claim: Improper and potentially bad-faith denial of medical coverage to named plaintiffs and putative class members based on AI-driven predictions rather than individualized medical necessity review.
claims.legal_basis: State insurance bad-faith and related common-law duties tied to fair, good-faith claims handling and individualized medical necessity determinations.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this stage; the court’s order concerns discovery structure only, and this claim proceeds with non-bifurcated discovery.

claims.claim: Class-action claims on behalf of similarly situated insureds whose coverage was allegedly denied or curtailed through use of nH Predict in violation of uniform contractual and legal obligations.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 and underlying state-law causes of action (contract and related insurance/consumer protections) supporting class-wide relief.
claims.outcome: Class certification not yet decided; court denies defendants’ request to limit or delay class discovery through bifurcation, allowing class-related discovery to proceed together with merits discovery.

defenses.defense: Request to bifurcate discovery so that discovery and litigation first focus only on the named plaintiffs’ individual merits before any class-wide or class-certification discovery occurs.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26 and 42(b), and the court’s inherent case-management authority to order phased or bifurcated discovery for efficiency and to avoid prejudice.

defenses.defense: Efficiency and burden argument that class-wide discovery regarding nH Predict and alleged systemic practices would be premature and unduly burdensome before resolving whether the named plaintiffs themselves have viable claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Case-management and proportionality principles under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) concerning scope and burden of discovery.

case_name: Zaletel v. Prisma Labs, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-powered photo app whose artistic filters are central to product and branding at issue.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on reverse confusion between the plaintiff’s registered PRIZMIA mark and defendant’s PRISMA mark for mobile photo and video applications.
claims.legal_basis: Federal trademark infringement under the Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1114 and related provisions on reverse confusion.
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits at the preliminary injunction stage and denied the motion for preliminary injunction.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and false designation of origin arising from defendant’s use of the PRISMA mark allegedly causing confusion with plaintiff’s PRIZMIA app.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a), 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a).
claims.outcome: Court concluded plaintiff failed to demonstrate a sufficient likelihood of confusion or irreparable harm and therefore denied preliminary injunctive relief.

defenses.defense: No likelihood of confusion between PRISMA and PRIZMIA marks, including in a reverse confusion theory, given differences in the marks, marketing, and consumer perception.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act trademark infringement standards; multi-factor likelihood-of-confusion analysis.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff cannot show irreparable harm from defendant’s continued use of PRISMA, so extraordinary relief in the form of a preliminary injunction is unwarranted.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable requirements for preliminary injunction under federal law (likelihood of irreparable harm).

defenses.defense: Plaintiff has not demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits of his trademark and unfair competition claims at this stage.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring likelihood of success on the merits.

case_name: Berg v. United Airlines et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff used AI to draft filings, which contained fake legal citations and violated court filing rules, leading to the striking of her summary-judgment responses.

claims.claim: Substantive civil claims against United Airlines (exact causes of action not specified in the summary).
claims.legal_basis: Unspecified federal and/or state civil claims alleged in the original complaint.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; case remains pending on United’s motion for summary judgment, with plaintiff given one final opportunity to file a procedurally proper response.

claims.claim: Plaintiff’s attempt to amend her complaint to add or change claims at a late stage of litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a) (amendments to pleadings) and Rule 16(b) (good cause to modify scheduling order).
claims.outcome: Denied; motion to amend the complaint was rejected for failure to comply with procedural rules and lack of good cause for late amendment.

claims.claim: Plaintiff’s filed responses in opposition to United Airlines’ motion for summary judgment (treated procedurally as her opposition to summary judgment).
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 56 and local court rules governing summary-judgment briefing, timeliness, and citation to legal authority.
claims.outcome: Stricken; the court granted United Airlines’ motion to strike these responses because they were untimely and relied on AI-generated content containing fake legal citations, violating court rules. Plaintiff was given one final chance to submit a compliant response by a specified deadline.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s opposition to summary judgment should be stricken as untimely and noncompliant with procedural rules.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 6 and 56, and local rules on filing deadlines and briefing requirements.
defenses.defense_outcome: Motion to strike granted; plaintiff’s existing responses were removed from the record.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s use of AI-generated content with fabricated legal citations renders her filings improper and contrary to court rules requiring accurate authority and counsel’s certification.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 11 (duty of candor and reasonable inquiry) and local rules requiring accurate citations and truthful representations to the court.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted in part; the court relied on the improper AI usage and fake citations as a basis to strike the filings and to warn plaintiff, but still allowed her one final opportunity to refile properly.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff should not be allowed to amend her complaint at this late stage because she failed to follow procedural requirements and show good cause for modification of the scheduling order.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 15(a) and 16(b) (standard for late amendments and good cause).
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; the court denied plaintiff’s request to amend the complaint.

case_name: Ryan v. X Corp.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleged X used an AI system to target and suspend his accounts without proper notice, forming part of his unfair business practices theory, but the court did not find this use of AI unlawful and dismissed all claims under the Terms of Service and Section 230.

claims.claim: Promissory fraud based on alleged promises that plaintiff’s accounts would not be suspended or would remain accessible if he complied with platform rules
claims.legal_basis: State-law promissory fraud; alleged misrepresentations and false promises by X Corp. regarding continued account access
claims.outcome: Dismissed; barred by X Corp.’s Terms of Service, which expressly allow account suspension and limit liability for such actions.

claims.claim: Promissory estoppel based on reliance on X Corp.’s alleged promises that his accounts would remain active or that enforcement would follow stated policies
claims.legal_basis: State-law promissory estoppel; plaintiff’s alleged detrimental reliance on X Corp.’s promises about account access and enforcement practices
claims.outcome: Dismissed; precluded by the Terms of Service that reserve X Corp.’s discretion to suspend accounts and disclaim liability, defeating any reasonable reliance.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment arising from X Corp. allegedly benefiting from plaintiff’s use, content, or payments while later suspending his accounts
claims.legal_basis: State-law unjust enrichment / restitution theory based on alleged inequitable retention of benefits by X Corp.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; independently barred by Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act and also inconsistent with the governing Terms of Service.

claims.claim: Unfair business practices based on account suspension and alleged use of AI to target and suspend his accounts without proper user notification
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition / unfair business practices statute (e.g., consumer protection law) premised on allegedly deceptive or unfair suspension practices and undisclosed AI-based enforcement
claims.outcome: Dismissed; claims foreclosed by X Corp.’s Terms of Service authorizing suspension and limiting liability, and not actionable in light of contractual provisions and Section 230 protections.

defenses.defense: Terms of Service authorize account suspension and limit liability for suspension-related harms
defenses.legal_basis: Contractual defense based on enforceable Terms of Service granting X Corp. broad discretion to suspend or terminate accounts and disclaiming liability for such actions.

defenses.defense: Section 230 immunity for moderation decisions and related claims, including unjust enrichment
defenses.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 230(c) and (e), providing immunity to interactive computer service providers for actions taken to restrict or remove content or accounts, barring plaintiff’s unjust enrichment and related claims.

case_id: 2024-03-14_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-05181_Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Playground AI LLC v. Mighty Computing, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Trademark dispute between AI-focused businesses over use of the “Playground AI” mark in connection with artificial intelligence products and services.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement against Mighty Computing and Suhail Doshi related to use of the 'Playground AI' mark
claims.legal_basis: Federal trademark law (Lanham Act) and related trademark principles
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss as to Suhail Doshi denied; trademark infringement claim against him may proceed based on plausible allegations of personal involvement.

claims.claim: Cybersquatting against Mighty Computing and Suhail Doshi for registering and using domain names incorporating the 'Playground AI' mark
claims.legal_basis: Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act (ACPA) and related federal cybersquatting provisions
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss as to Suhail Doshi denied; cybersquatting claim against him may proceed based on plausible allegations of personal involvement.

defenses.defense: Corporate officer immunity from personal liability for acts of the corporation
defenses.legal_basis: General corporate law principle that officers are not personally liable for corporate trademark violations absent direct participation or control

defenses.defense: Insufficient factual allegations tying Suhail Doshi personally to the alleged infringement and cybersquatting
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Rule 12(b)(6) and Twombly/Iqbal requirement for plausible, non-conclusory allegations
